div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THREE or four years having elapſed ſince the repreſentation of the following trifle, it will, no doubt, be thought extraordinary, that it ſhould make its appearance in print juſt at the time when ſo capital a production as The SCHOOL for SCANDAL engroſſes all theatrical attention: in ſome degree to excuſe the ill-timing of this publication, the author aſſures the public, that the copy-right was diſpoſed of, and ſome ſheets of it in the preſs, before that Comedy appeared; otherwiſe they would never have been troubled with this apology, or the cauſe of it.

TO THE LADIES and GENTLEMEN, Who, by their admirable performance of this firſt eſſay, and excellent delivery of the prologue and epilogue to it, obtained ſuch applauſe to them, as in themſelves they could not merit, The MAID of KENT Is moſt gratefully inſcribed, by their much obliged Servant,

lg.l: WHEN a melodious lark, aſcending, ſings,
The wide expanſe with ſhrilly echoes rings;
'Till, ſtrongly winging his aerial way,
To ſight he's loſt, warbling his heav'n-tun'd lay!
Not ſo, when the young bird firſt 'ttempts a flight,
Emerging from his neſt to dazzling light—
With flutt'ring pinions, half-form'd notes, dim'd eyes,
From the too pow'rful glare, he, trembling, hies
To ſome thick wood, low copſe, or ſhady grove,
Where he, ſecure from birds of prey, may rove;
Where ſafely he may try his feeble wings,
There flits from ſpray to ſpray, and faintly ſings:
Patient remains 'till ſtrength and art are won,
Then ſoars and warbles 'gainſt the noon-day ſun!
But, when he ventures firſt t'explore the ſky,
Should critic-buzzard, hawk, or kite be nigh,
Skimming and winding round, then on him dart,
His beak and talons dig into his heart;
No more he ſings, no more can ever fly,
His artleſs ſong and ſelf together die!
So will it fare with our green-bird or ſparrow,
If, grov'ling found, you o'er him draw the harrow;
No more he'll chirrup his inſipid note,
Or vainly gurgle his diſcordant throat:
O loſs of loſſes!—ne'er to be recover'd—
A green-bird in a furrow you have ſmother'd!
But ſay you're merciful, and, 'ſtead of killing
The vent'rous fool, to rear him ſhould be willing;
Pleas'd, he'll crack rape-ſeed, bucket raiſe of water,
T' amuſe yourſelf, ſpouſe, ſon, and pretty daughter;
And while he grunſell picks, or chickweed eats,
Will, chirping, thank each gen'rous heart that treats;
May learn the linnet's, lark's, canary's ſong,
His tuneful life if kindly you prolong;
And ſtrive each hour t'improve his ſimple lay,
In clearer ſtrains your favours to repay!

div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
div.p: Scene—Sir Thomas Richacre's Seat, near the Seacoaſt, in Kent.

div.head: ACT I. Scene a Study in Sir Thomas Richacre's Houſe. Doctor Goodman and Emily are diſcovered ſitting: the Doctor ſhutting a Book, they preſently riſe.

sp.speaker: Dr. GOODMAN.
sp.p: HERE, madam, if you pleaſe, we'll conclude the labour of the day.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Call it rather the pleaſure of the day, ſir,—for ſuch it is to me, I aſſure you—to you indeed, ſir, I fear it muſt be otherwiſe—the inſtruction of a ſilly girl, no doubt, is painful and tedious.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Pardon me, madam, I did not call it labour in that ſenſe; ſo far am I from thinking it irkſome, the hours I paſs in this our every morning's exerciſe, and the duties of my holy function, are the happieſt of my life:—for, believe me, were you my own child, inſtead of my honour'd patron's, I could not love you better!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Nor do I think Sir Thomas's affection (altho' the beſt of fathers) exceeds the very paternal regard you have ever been pleaſed to expreſs for me—and—I know not why—I
think I feel not a more filial love for him, than for yourſelf, ſir!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Dear madam, ſay not ſo:—the many hours we paſs together in our delightful ſtudies, beget in you a cuſtomary regard— think it no more.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Perhaps it is no more, ſir, nay, it cannot—for never had a child a kinder parent!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Nor ever had a man a truer friend! Indeed, ſo general is his goodneſs, he might be a pattern for mankind:—he never ſaw an infant without a parent's fondneſs, or a grey head, but, like a child, he honour'd it!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ha, ha! what, hard at it?—What is it?—Ethics or mathematics, aſtrology or theology?—'tis a thouſand pities, Doctor, your pupil is a girl, otherwiſe ſhe would certainly be a biſhop in time.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Perhaps not, papa;—you ſee Dr. Goodman, with as much piety, learning, good ſenſe, and, I am ſure, as good a heart as any, has hitherto attained to no greater dignities than rector of this pariſh, your chaplain, ſir, and my tutor.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Were I, madam, what you are pleaſed to ſay of me, it does not at all follow I ſhould ever be ſo exalted.—There are, no doubt, an infinitely greater number of deſerving miniſters than there are mitres, or even inferior dignities; but whoever has attained to that of an honeſt man, will feel, that church or ſtate can never raiſe him higher!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: I think ſo too, Doctor; and, in that reſpect, there is not a more exalted character than yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, ſir!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: But all this while I forget your boy, Doctor.—I made my morning's airing ſhorter than uſual, that I might be in the way when he arrived.—He is not come yet, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: No, ſir.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Does young Mr. Goodman come home from Oxford to day, ſir?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Yes, madam, I expect him.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Bleſs me! I thought he was not to have come till next week, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he'll be here to day, and then you may have a new tutor, for I ſuppoſe you have almoſt tir'd your old one.—I warrant, by this time, he can ſpeak Greek as well as his father; what think you, Doctor?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: I not only think that of him, ſir, but, were he not my own, I could be bold to ſay, he is the moſt accompliſhed youth I ever ſaw, and, add to that—the beſt!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ay, ay, George is a good boy!— ay, and a clever one too—every body ſays ſo as well as yourſelf:—but if they did not, the crow, you know, always thinks her own young whiteſt, ha, ha, ha!—Let me ſee, [looking at his watch] 'tis paſt one,—will the rogue be here to dinner, think you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: I expect him every moment, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Od! I wish he was come! I have not ſeen him this age:—and are not you glad he is coming, Emily?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Yes, indeed, ſir, very glad—for I think him a moſt amiable young man; and
have often thought it a thouſand pities he is not heir to a good fortune; as this idolatrous world of ours, ſtill worshipping a golden calf, would value him much more for inheriting a fund of wealth than virtues:—and a rich coxcomb is oftner propoſed to us poor girls, than the moſt deſerving of our affections, whoſe merits are not back'd with that powerful recommendation—a great eſtate!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: It's very true, my dear,—too often the caſe, I muſt confeſs.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And I make no doubt, but even our ridiculous worthleſs neighbour, Lord Sealand's addreſſes, would be eſteemed an honour, and plain George Goodman's, an affront, to moſt great families in the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why, he is a peer of the realm, you know.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: True, papa; and there are very few ſo ill-bred, as to think a coronet may ſometimes cover a weak head, or a glittering ſtar, a bad heart!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ha, ha! well ſaid, my little ſatiriſt!—We are to be honour'd with his lordship's company to day at dinner, on purpoſe to ſee George.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: His lordship has been always kind enough to take great notice of my poor boy.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: That is the only proof of underſtanding he ever gave—and, but for that, he would be intolerable, with his unaccountable whims and caprices.—Now own, papa, don't you think it a ſtrange amuſement he has lately taken to, keeping ſailing veſſels, to be ſo often toſſing about on the ſea as he is?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why ay, child, I think it rather too boiſterous to be called pleaſure; but he ſeldom makes a much longer trip than juſt acroſs to Calais, to furnish himſelf with ſome of their knicknacks and fopperies.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Right, papa; for ſuch a finical waterfly is he, that, when on shore, he lays out more money in powder and perfumes in a week, than, I fear, he gives to the poor in a year.—I never ſee him, papa, but I think of beau Mizen in the play. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Well, but, Emily, my dear, you, of all people in the world, should not be ſo ſevere upon him: he's a very warm admirer of you, you know; and has almoſt aſk'd my conſent to marry you.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: He is not a bit more in my good graces for that, I aſſure you, papa; for, could he obtain your conſent, I believe he'd care very little whether he had mine or not.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: But Sir Thomas, I am perſuaded, madam, will never grant one without the other.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: That I confide in, ſir.—I ſuppoſe I shall be teiz'd to death with his ſupercilious nonſenſe to day, which he gives me to underſtand he means for courtship.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: And are not you delighted at the very idea of being his lady?—Counteſs of Sealand!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Not I, indeed, papa; lud! lud! what a character! a foppish ſailor! a compound of tar and civet! faugh!—I'd ſooner marry our honeſt Old Metre yonder, and be dame to the clerk of the pariſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! here comes the old pſalm-ſinger as faſt as he can hobble.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Poor good old man! he's worth a court-calendar full of ſuch lords!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Your reverence! your reverence!— goodlack, I moſt humbly crave your worship's pardon for my abrupt intruſion, [to Sir Thomas] but I come a joyful harbinger! As I am a ſinner, ſir, your well-beloved ſon is juſt arrived. [to the Doctor.]

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Is he faith, old Sternhold?

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Yes, in truth, your worship, or may I never ſet another ſtave.

sp.speaker: Emity.
sp.p: [Looking out.] O lud, ay! he is juſt ſtepping out of the poſt-chaiſe—bleſs me—what a figure I am!—I—I beg pardon, ſir, but indeed I can't ſtay—I muſt go and make myſelf a little more fit to be ſeen?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Did you obſerve the girl, Doctor?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Moſt heedfully, ſir—and fear—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: He approacheth, your honours, he approacheth!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ay, here he comes, ſure enough.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Your bleſſing, ſir, [kneeling to Dr. Goodman.]

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Heaven grant thee grace!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: My honour'd patron! my ſecond father! [to Sir Thomas] I can't reſiſt an impulſe that throws me at your feet, and bids me beg your bleſſing too!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs and preſerve you, my good lad!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: My dear father, forgive this tranſport —I fear it hurries me into a neglect, I'd ſooner die than willingly be guilty of —but—this meeting overpowers me!—don't be offended, ſir, [to Sir Thomas] at the frankneſs of a poor lad like me—indeed I am very happy to ſee you, ſir! I hope both you, ſir, and my dear father, are as well as—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Well? odzookers! who can be ill and look ſuch a ruddy-cheek'd rogue as you in the face?—faith, you look bravely, my lad!— and a devilish handſome young dog you are grown! rare work, I warrant, he has made at Oxford, Doctor! how many dozen have you left crying their eyes out, eh, George?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: You are merry, ſir,

sp.speaker: Sir. Thom.
sp.p: Well, but—joking apart—have you left ne'er a little tender ſoul breaking her heart after you;—a ſweetheart, eh, George? for I'll engage you have got one, boy.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: To what end, ſir, ſo young and unprovided for, as I am?—But, excuſe me, ſir, for interrupting you by hoping Miſs Richacre is well.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ay, Emily is pure hearty, and as reſerv'd as yourſelf—She wont confeſs the power of the little blind boy any more than you.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: The longer ſhe is, ſir, before ſhe makes her choice, we may reaſonably hope the better it will be.—But, I believe, ſir, she may wait long indeed, before she finds one to deſerve her.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Odzookers, George, that's a civiler thing than ever I heard Lord Sealand ſay of her, with all his courtship.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Lord Sealand! [aſide] I—I hope, ſir, I do not offend in ſpeaking my ſentiments ſo freely?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Offend! no, no, boy—I like you the better for ſpeaking your thoughts—I wish all mankind did ſo, they would not be the worſe for it.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Then, with your worship's indulgence, I can withhold no longer—As I am an unworthy ſinner, ſir, [to George] I am more delighted to behold you than a full congregation! and that is the delight of my old heart.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What, my good old friend! nothing but my extreme joy at ſeeing my honour'd parent and protector, could have made me overlook you—I am very glad to ſee you—I hope you are well! [taking Metre kindly by the hand.]

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: In troth, the better for ſeeing you well, ſir! [wiping his eyes.]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Ah, my old playfellow, "Thou haſt born me on this back a thouſand times!"

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: And a pleaſant load thou wert, my ever gentle taſk-maſter! he, he, he!—and, in like ſportful ſort, although I am waxen old, I hope to live to bear your tender offspring!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: No, my poor Yorick! time will, I fear, bear you away firſt!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p:
Not ſo neither, George—for, as my mother uſed to ſay to me, thoſe eyes of yours will make many a pretty girl's heart ach—ſo, don't be timorous, lad, but look about you; and, if you take a liking to a girl, let her be who she may, attack her boldly—I am a
whimſical old fellow, and if I take it into my head, may make you worth her having.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Sir, I fear your goodneſs will—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Pho, pho, be quiet, Doctor—you know I am not (like too many in the world) eaſily talked out of a good deſign, or into a bad one—but, tell us, George, ſincerely, now we are upon the ſubject, have you really ne'er a ſweetheart at Oxford?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: No, I aſſure you, ſir.—I never ſaw a face there that made the leaſt impreſſion on me.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: And you are heart-whole, ha?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: As when I left this houſe, ſir! [ſighing aſide.]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why, how have you paſs'd your time, lad? always at your ſtudies?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Pretty conſtantly, ſir—the only return in my power for your great bounty to me, was the making a proper uſe of it.—But, if I may be ſo bold, ſir, I think you mentioned ſomething of Lord Sealand's having paid his addreſſes to Miſs Richacre.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ay, George, I believe I might—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: But I think, ſir, you ſaid too, that Miſs Emily had not hitherto confeſs'd any particular inclination—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why, no—but he's very rich— and when a ſuitor is both wealthy and noble, you know—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Very true, ſir!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p:
Not that I believe Emily likes him a jot better for thoſe accidental advantages, as ſhe calls them—She and I are much of a mind about him; for, in my opinion,
he is but a frothy kind of a ſpark, like too many of the preſent age—and it is paying you no compliment, George, to ſay ſuch a lad as you are, is worth a ſcore ſuch as Lord Sealand. [George bows reſpectfully.]

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: I fear, ſir, what you are pleaſed to ſay of my poor boy will make him vain.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Vain of what ſuch an old fellow as I ſay! no, no,—If Emily had ſaid as much indeed—but, Doctor, I muſt rob you of George's company a little—come, boy,—you muſt go and aſk my girl how ſhe is—ſhe'll be glad to ſee you, I'm ſure—She juſt ſaw you alight, and ſcamper'd away to ſet her cap ſtrait, or ſome ſuch important matter—Come along, my boy, and I'll promiſe you a kiſs for your pains.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Will you excuſe me a few moments, my dear ſir, while I pay my reſpects to Miſs Richacre?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Ay, ay, attend Sir Thomas by all means—meantime, I'll ſtep and ſee a poor cottager hard by, who, Metre has juſt been telling me, is very ill.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: You are as humane as ever, ſir, heaven bleſs you!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: And you too, my dear boy!

div.stage: Exeunt Dr. Goodman and George ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p:
Amen! and heaven be with you both! for ſuch a father and ſuch a ſon, are hardly to be parallel'd!—No marvel his good worship is ſo well pleaſed in ye—he, wheſe benignity extendeth even unto my unworthy ſelf, and my poor child, Martha; whom he hath moſt benevolently reared, as waiting-maid
unto his fair daughter, from childhood even unto womanhood—and, in commiſeration of my forlorn condition, when my loving helpmate, Rebecca, departed this tranſitory life, bountifully took me to end my days in peace in his moſt hoſpitable manſion!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Lord, ma'am, there's nobody here but my father—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Whom ſeeketh her good ladyship, Martha?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I thought Mr. Goodman had been here.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: No, madam—his reverence is gone to viſit the afflicted.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: O, no—I don't mean the Doctor, but George Goodman—I met his father this moment, and he ſaid he was this way.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Good madam, I moſt humbly crave forgiveneſs for my miſapprehenſion—my dearly beloved young maſter departed hence but even now indeed, to accompany his worship, in order to pay his moſt dutiful reſpects unto your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Run, Patty—tell my papa I came down the other ſtairs, and am here.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: So pleaſe your ladyship, I will acquaint his worship forthwith.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Metre.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: I long for the ſweet young pair to meet methinks!
sp.l: Would it might be never to part again—
That I devoutly pray, and to it add—Amen!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And ſo, Patty, you did ſee him, you ſay?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, I juſt had a peep at him as he paſſed thro' the hall, and he did look ſo handſome you can't think.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I wish you are not in love with him, girl.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Ah, madam! if I was as much his betters as he is mine, I'd ſoon tell him a piece of my mind.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Why really the youth's not amiſs— I had a glimpſe of him myſelf, and think him conſiderably improved, I muſt confeſs—his complexion more florid, and air more lively than when he left us.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Ay, ma'am, that he is, more lively and more lovely too than ever; and ſo you would ſay, ma'am, I am ſure, if you ſpoke your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Indeed! and pray how came you ſo well acquainted with my thoughts?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Why, ma'am, the dreſſing glaſs diſcovered them to me—for you have look'd more in it ſince you knew young Mr. Goodman was arrived, than ever I knew you in all my life before—And I'll be whipt if you don't wish to appear as handſome in his eyes as he does in yours.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: O you wicked girl, how can you ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Indeed, ma'am, if I was as rich as your ladyſhip, and we were both at our own diſpoſal, I fancy we should puzzle the poor young gentleman which to chooſe—for his choice he might have, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And, in that caſe, you think he'd be puzzled which to chooſe?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: O, dear ma'am, I had quite forgot one thing—that is—If I was as beautiful as your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: O, your ladyship's moſt obedient! [curtſying] and ſo you have quite forgot your ſweetheart, William?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: William?—yes—no, ma'am—that is —O gemini, ma'am, here the ſweet gentleman comes as ſure as a gun!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Eh! what! where?

div.stage: Sir Thomas Richacre and George enter.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Here, Emily, my girl, where are you? I was juſt going to ſtorm your dreſſing room as old Amen overtook me—I have brought an old acquaintance to ſee you.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: With your leave, ſir— [offering to ſalute Emily.]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ay, ay, kiſs her, boy, kiſs her!— and kiſs him, girl! you two muſt not be ſtrange.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Madam!—I—I hope— [ſaluting her.]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Sir!—I am—very— [both heſitate thro' confuſion.]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p:
Heyday! Madam—I hope—and, Sir, I am very—and there they both ſtop!— why what ail you both? you are not tonguetied ſure all on a ſudden?—Pray, ſir,—what may you hope?—and, ma'am,—what are you very?—come, come, I fancy I can explain the matter—I ſuppoſe, George, if the truth was known, you hope to get another kiſs—and you, Emily, are very willing to give it him! well,
well, with all my heart, never heed me—kiſs her again, boy, kiſs her again!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Sir, I beg pardon for—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Pho, pho, kiſs her again, I tell you—I inſiſt upon it—and then, perhaps, you'll recover your ſpeech a little.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: [Saluting her again] I am ſo overjoy'd, madam—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Sir, I am extremely— [They ſtand bowing and curtſying confuſedly▪]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: [To Sir Thom.] Dear heart, ſir, I hope you won't be angry, but indeed I cant hold my tongue any longer—You're welcome to Kent, ſir! I hope you are well, ſir? [Curtſying to George.]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Very well, I thank you, Patty.—I am glad to ſee you—I hope you are well?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Pretty well, 'thank you, ſir; how do you do?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why look you there now—I warrant Miſtreſs Patt could hold on a—how d'ye do, ſir? and a—pretty well, thank you, ſir! till this day fortnight; [mimicking Patty] while you ſtand as mute as an Egyptian mummy.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Dear papa, forgive me.—Sir—I beg your pardon, but indeed I was ſo glad to ſee you, I had ſcarce power to tell you ſo!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: You have bereft me, madam, of reply, by ſaying the very words I would have utter'd if I could—may I flatter myſelf ſo far as to think—

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: O yes, indeed, ſir, you may flatter yourſelf—for my lady and I are both very glad to ſee you!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, you chatter-box! I don't know any buſineſs you have here.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Dear heart, ſir! I did but juſt ſpeak —Chatter-box!—I wiſh I had been as cunning as ſome folks, and held my tongue, I might then have been kiſs'd a little as well as ſome other people. [aſide.]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Pray, papa, excuſe her—ſhe always ſeem'd to have ſo great reſpect for Mr. Goodman, and was ſo deſirous now of ſeeing him, that I gave her leave to come with me.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: So pleaſe your worſhip, the right honourable the Earl of Sealand is juſt alighting from his gilded cha-ri-ot.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: I'll go to him directly—children, I'll leave you to yourſelves a little—you'll find your tongues, perhaps, when my back's turn'd —but, George, you have not much time to ſpare—Lord Sealand will be enquiring for you, ſo get dreſs'd as ſoon as poſſible.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I will, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Come along then, old Pitch-pipe, and young madam Prate-a-pace!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: We follow your good and merry worſhip! ha, ha, ha! Martha, my child, come your ways.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: I'll come preſently, father—I am in great hopes he will kiſs me yet!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Preſently will not do, child, come now! [aſide to her] Wilt thou never learn more manners than to hearken unto gentlefolks' diſcourſe? an eves-dropper! fie for ſhame! get thee gone about thy buſineſs, that's my good girl.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: [aſide] Psha! fiddle, faddle! how provoking this is! now I am ſure I sha'n't get a kiſs.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: [to Emily] Your honour's very humble ſervant! heaven bleſs you, my ſweet young maſter!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: And you too, my good old friend!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Juſt ſuch a lovely pair were thoſe firſt formed—ah! would your conditions were as equal! then might I hope, ere long, unto your nuptial benediction, moſt joyfully to cry Amen!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [ſmiling] What a whimſical old ſoul it is!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: But exceeding kind and honeſt—at leaſt to me—he knows no bounds to his good wishes for my welfare—which is all I can ſay in extenuation of his freedom now to you, madam!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: O, the well-meaning good creature cannot eaſily offend me.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Have a care, dear madam, your condeſcenſion don't deſtroy the reſpect I should preſerve—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Let me beg of you to forget thoſe diſtant words, reſpect, and madam—our compliments are over, (tho' with much difficulty) [ſmiling] let us now reſume that innocent familiarity we were bred together in, and ever were delighted with—when we parted laſt, you was leſs ceremonious; then, inſtead of madam, you call'd me your Emily—nay more, your dear Emily!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: That I ſtill might without a crime! for ſure there can be nothing dearer to me.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Then why this diſtance—this reſerve?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: O Emily! think but of your condition, your rank in life, and think of mine!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And ſhall that lay a reſtraint upon our lips?—muſt they be denied to expreſs what our hearts will feel, forgetful of diſtinction?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What my heart feels they can't expreſs—gratitude, love, admiration! all the moſt ſuſceptible can feel, or eloquent deſcribe, is there.—My deareſt Emily, ſtill I muſt call you ſo—why are you thus kind—thus condeſcending!—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: In what?—'prithee, now, where is the mighty difference between us? is not your father in every reſpect (but the loweſt of all conſiderations, riches) as good as mine? and wherein can I pretend to vie with thee, who art an abſtract of both their virtues!—but we grow ſerious—beſides, you have to dreſs, and ſee that odious Sealand, which this detains you from; ſo, 'till we meet at dinner, dear George, adieu!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Adieu, ſweet Emily! lovely, engaging, bewitching Emily! O that I were but rich enough to dare aſpire to thee! never did I repine at want of fortune but on thy account, and when I find that the only bar to my ſucceſs, I muſt repine; ſince, were I not the child of poverty and dependance, what might I not hope!—her partiality for me, I think, is evident—and my determination to conquer this ill-ſuited paſſion, ſhe has, in one moment, utterly deſtroyed! [he ſtands muſing]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: I gave my father the ſlip nicely— and here he is yet—and alone too, that's charming! Now, who knows but I may have better luck than I had before [aſide]—Pray, ſir, is not my young lady here? [George does not obſerve her.] Hoity toity! why he's ſpeechleſs again—may be he is always ſo when he wants to kiſs a pretty girl—I wiſh Sir Thomas wou'd pop in his head, and cry (as he did juſt now) kiſs her, boy! kiſs her again! [aſide.]— Sir! Sir!—pray is not madam Emily here?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: [Starting from his reverie.] Ha! Emily! what of Emily?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Nothing, ſir,—only I thought ſhe had been here—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, no—ſhe has juſt left me—the happieſt, yet moſt wretched, of mankind! [aſide.]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p:
Not one kiſs, by jingo! I could cry for madneſs! I ſuppoſe he's proud, and thinks himſelf too much above me—marry come up! and yet—he is a pretty gentleman, and if I was as rich as a jew I'd marry him directly.— Stay—let me conſider—I have got a little money by me that my father knows nothing of, if I don't buy a lottery-ticket I'll be burnt!—and if I get the twenty-thouſand-pound-prize, nay, if I am ſo unlucky as to get only the ten-thouſand, I'll tell him my mind directly—and ſure then he won't think himſelf above me! I've heard ſay, that in London the gentry—ay, even your lords and dukes, now and then marry poor girls that are pretty—like me, for
love—nay, (tho' I hardly know how to believe it) folks ſay, they'll ſometimes take up with their own, ay, or other people's, kept-madams! and I am ſure it wou'd not be a quarter ſo bad as that, for a parſon's ſon to marry a clerk's daughter!

div.head: ACT II. Scene, Sir Thomas Richacre's Garden.—A Summer Houſe in view.—Metre comes out of the Summer Houſe, William meets him carrying a Chair.

sp.speaker: WILLIAM.
sp.p: HERE, maſter Metre, here be another chair, and now it be all right, I believe —there be two for madam Emily and young maſter Goodman—two elbow-ones for Sir Thomas and his reverence, and this gilded damaſk one you bid me fetch for my lord—but ecod, if I was his worſhip, I'd ſet upon it myſelf.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—well, put it into the ſummer-houſe with the reſt, that's my good lad.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Never ſtir if I don't believe it be made of lead, it feels ſo plaguy heavy—thof I ſuppoſe I only think ſo 'cauſe I fetch'd it with an ill-will—for, to be ſure, I did grudge my labour moſt confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Why ſo, William? I never knew thee idle yet—Why ſo?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Why, becauſe I don't like un—and it goes mortally again' the grain with me to do any thing for ſuch a ſcape-grace—for, as the ould ſaving be—he is like the wind at eaſt, good to neither man nor beaſt!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: For ſhame, William, for ſhame! you should not ſpeak ſo diſreſpectfully of a nobleman.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Nobleman! why I hope, maſter Metre, you don't think ſuch a whiffling chap as Lord Sealand deſerves to be called noble? I'll be judg'd by yourſelf now, if he be one crumb like his worship, or a quarter ſo noble, —thof he be no more but a knight-barrow-knight.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: I profeſs, William, I do not think this light young lord ſo deſerving of his dignity as our nobles in general are ſaid to be; which maketh me moſt heartily wiſh he was more like his worſhip's honour than he is.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: More like un! I'll be ſhot an' he be a bit like un—no more than a crab-apple be like a golden-pippin! I wonder, for my part (nay, for that matter, ſo do the whole neighbourhood) why ſuch a good gentleman as Sir Thomas, keeps company with him, and lets him come dangling here for ever a'ter young madam, like a tantony-pig?

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p:
Why, thou knoweſt, William, his lordſhip hath a great eſtate adjoining to his worſhip's—and, although he hath it not in his will, I fear, to do much good, it is in his power to do a great deal of harm, therefore,
I conjecture, his worship holdeth it prudent to keep friends with him.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: More the pity, I ſay, maſter Metre, that what few good men there be in the world ſhould be obligated to truckle to the bad—or that any one ſhould have a good eſtate that has not a good heart likewiſe!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: William! thou art an honeſt righteous lad, I verily believe; and, although it hath pleaſed heaven to place thee in ſo humble a ſtation, the uprightneſs of thy heart would adorn the princes and the rulers of the land, more than their coſtly raiment, precious ſtones, purple and fine linen!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Thanks to your kind opinion, maſter Metre—I do hope I shall never prove no otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: I am morally certain thou wilt not— hold forth thy hand—there is a shilling for thee—and I will beſtow upon thee too a donation of good books, particularly, the Old and New Teſtament, the Liturgy, with, thereunto annexed, the Old and New Verſion of the Pſalms of David, done into English Metre.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: 'Thank you kindly—odſbobs, I shall be quite ſet up—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Moreover, I will recommend thee unto his reverence, to ſucceed me in my holy office upon my demiſe—

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: What, me to be clerk and ſexton! oh lord!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p:
To qualify thee for which important undertaking, I will inſtruct thee in every thing appertaining unto a clerkship—particularly in pſalmody—likewiſe how to adapt, as well as
ſet, a ſtave—and eke alſo, both audibly and emphatically to cry Amen!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: I shall ſoon learn, for I know all the notches already, and can give the key with the pitch-pipe, and ſing fol fa with e'er a he in the parish—and as to Amen—no offence, maſter Metre, I hope—but I could ſay it twice as laudable as you do.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Audible, thou would'ſt ſay, William —and audibly did I uſe to ſay it—but, alackaday, I am waxen old, and my voice is impaired—but when I was thy age—hem! A—a—men!

div.stage: Speaking as loud as he can, William puts his hand before Metre's mouth.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Odſbobs! here comes my lady.

div.stage: Emily enters—William carries the Chair into the Summer Houſe—Metre is going, Emily recalls him.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No, not here!—where is my George? what can have become of him?—Mr. Metre!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Did your good ladyship pleaſe to call?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Are you going into the houſe, pray?

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Unleſs your ladyship hath occaſion to ſend me elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No, only be ſo good to tell Patty I want to ſpeak with her.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: I will communicate your ladyship's pleaſure unto her incontinently.—Ah! when young, I had a voice like any bell!—and, as the old ſong ſayeth, could dig a grave, and ſet a ſtave, and ſay Amen full well! [aſide as he goes off.]

div.stage: Exit Metre.—William returns, and is following Metre, Emily calls him.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: William!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Step to the cottage below our garden-door in the green-lane; I am told the poor labourer there is ill, and the family in great diſtreſs—give this to the poor woman— [gives money and be careful not to mention it to any body elſe, I charge you.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: No, indeed, ma'am, I'll never open my lips about it, but when I'm praying heaven to bleſs and preſerve your ladyship's goodneſs!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Run then, William, as faſt as you can; and go out at the garden-door, that none of our family may ſee you.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, I will—I'm ſure I should not think this a heavy load if it weigh'd as much again as the gilt chair, for I should like to be ſo employ'd from one week's end to the other!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: What a humane creature! ſuch goodneſs muſt not go unrewarded.—How different are our natures! this uninſtructed boy, poſſeſſing virtues too ſeldom met with in the moſt exalted!—What then avail a pompous title, wealth, and illuſtrious anceſtry? ſince the meaneſt peaſant, poſſeſſing but humanity, has no ſuperior! while the heart that cannot feel for others' woes, diſgraces, not only a diſtinguished rank, but even our very nature!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Did you want me, ma'am? my father ſaid—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Yes, Patty; my papa intends paſſing the afternoon in the ſummer-houſe, ſo order coffee and tea to be ſerved there.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Patty—have you ſeen any thing of young Mr. Goodman ſince dinner?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, I ſaw him ſteal ſlily by the hall windows a little while ago—I don't know where he went, but I have a notion he has ſeen ſome trollop in the neighbourhood, as he came along in the poſt-chaiſe, that he has taken a liking to, and is gone in ſearch of— and I'm ſure that's a shame, when he might pick and chooſe out of the two prettieſt in the whole county!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Why, Patty, this is love in downright earneſt—I'll be whipt if you have not quite forgot poor William, and are jealous of this young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Jealous! not I indeed, ma'am—William is worth a dozen of him—young gentleman! he don't behave like one, that's what he don't, for he has not once had the good manners to offer to ſalute me ſince he came home.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Poor Patty! that is provoking, indeed—

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am—I believe you'd think it was, if he had ſerv'd you ſo!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Indeed! ha, ha, ha! why I wish you are not jealous of me next.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p:
No, ma'am, I am pretty ſecure there, if I really did like him well enough to care about him—for, your ladyship being heireſs to ſo many thouſand pounds a year, he would
never dare to make love to you, ma'am—and I hope, ma'am, ſetting caſe you was weak enough to like the poor lad, you'd never demean yourſelf ſo much as to tell him ſo.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I don't know that, Patty; for ſetting caſe (as you phraſe it) I lik'd him, I ſhould make very little ſcruple of confeſſing it.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Indeed! lord, lord, how little pride ſome people have! If I was a baronet's daughter, I'd never think of taking up with a poor clergyman's ſon, when I might marry a lord, and be a counteſs.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: A mind like his would reflect a luſtre upon the meaneſt origin! and I deſire, Patty, you would reſtrain this freedom, nor make ſo free with Mr. Goodman's name again.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Dear heart, ma'am, I did but juſt ſpeak—and I ſhould not have ſaid what I have, had not your ladyſhip aſk'd me about him—if I am a little jealous of him, there's ſomebody to the full as jealous of me!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: How I am tormented with this ſilly girl, while my mind is rack'd with a thouſand apprehenſions! [aſide]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: You wanted coffee and tea ſerv'd in the ſummer-houſe, I think you ſaid, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Yes, child! [peeviſhly.]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Child! goodlack!—ay—ſhe is in love with him as ſure as a gun, as well as myſelf—I'm ſure I won't buy a lottery ticket ſince that's the caſe, for, 'twou'd be only throwing my money away! [aſide]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Heyday! what ails the fooliſh girl! I wiſh she is not jealous in good earneſt—and —what's the matter with the other foolish
girl! I wish ſhe is not more affected than she ought—for, were I certain George was abſolutely gone upon the errand Patty mentioned, I believe—I should not be very well pleas'd!—but it cannot be—therefore be ſtill, my heart! poor frighten'd fool! nor throb and flutter without cauſe!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Ma'am, I ha'run as hard as ever I cou'd, and the poor ſouls ſend their duty and ten thouſand thanks to your ladyship—but, bleſſed be providence, they ſay, they don't want any money now.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: How ſo, William?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Why, ma'am, what d'ye think? when I went into the cot, who should I ſee ſitting by the ſick man but young Maſter Goodman; and thof the poor ſoul be ſo bad, 'twould ha' puzzled a ſtranger to tell which of the two ail'd moſt, young gentleman look'd ſo piteouſly.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Indeed! was young Mr. Goodman there?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: My mind's at reſt again! [aſide]

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: And the poor woman told me he had been there a good while, and had writ a deſcription to be made up at 'pottecary's for her huſband, and had guve 'em money to pay for it, and more to buy victuals with, and kiſs'd the ſweet babes, and was ſo kind to 'em, nothing could be like it!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: The dear, the amiable youth! how could I wrong him by my late ungenerous fears! [aſide]

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: And when I came out, ma'am, who should I ſee but his worship and Dr. Goodman, and they ax'd me what I had been doing there, and what I was crying about— for, to be ſure, young gentleman's goodneſs had made my eyes water a little—and when I told 'em, I wish I may never ſtir if their honours did not almoſt cry too!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And where did my papa and the doctor go, William?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Why where do you think they went, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Nay, how can I tell?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: I am ſure it made my heart dance with joy, to ſee ſuch a grand gentleman as Sir Thomas Richacre, a knight-barrow-knight, juſtice of peace and quorum, ſtoop to go into a poor hovel like that—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: What, the cottage you had juſt come out of!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, ma'am—into poor Quickſet's little hut!—but I cou'd not ſee Lord Sealand, thof I look'd all about—and if he had gone along with their honours, his coat wou'd not ha' ſet the worſe on his back o' Sunday, as the ſaying be—axing your ladyship's pardon!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Indeed, William, I am entirely of your mind—but, if I was not, why do you aſk my pardon? it is not me you are ſpeaking againſt.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p:
Noa, madam, mercy forbid! it's out of any one's power to ſay ill of your ladyship—
but it be rife all over the parish that your ladyship's going to be married to my lord, and there's not a living ſoul but what pities you: for your ladyship's as much belov'd as my lord's hated—and to be ſure, that's not a little.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Well, William, I am not married to his lordship yet—and 'till I am, you need not fear offending me by ſuch remarks.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Thank your ladyship's goodneſs— does your ladyship pleaſe to want any thing elſe?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No, 'thank you, William, not at preſent.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: [aſide as he is going] Now I know the poor ſouls don't want for any thing, if I can but coax Patty into a good humour, I shall be as happy as a king—Odrabbit it! I axe ten thouſand pardons, but if I had not like to ha' forgot to remember to give your ladyship the piece of gold again, I'll be shot.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: William, you are a humane good lad, and shall not want encouragement—keep it yourſelf as an earneſt of what I may do farther for you.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: 'Thank you kindly and heartily, ma'am!—it be more your goodneſs than my deſert— [aſide] now I'll run back again to the cottage t'other way, and watch 'till their honours be gone in at garden door, then make the poor ſouls have the money, whether they will or not!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Married to Lord Sealand! I shudder to hear it mentioned! whence could ſuch a report take riſe? from himſelf, or from Sir
Thomas? ſure my dear father, kind to all beſides, will never ſingle me out to be cruel to! and (as he does nothing without his worthy friend's advice) ſurely the good, the pious Doctor Goodman never can approve it! —why should I fear then?—and yet I do— the bare idea that it is poſſible makes me tremble—gracious heaven! how dreadful is my preſent ſituation! demanded by a worthleſs inſolent I deteſt! hopeleſs of him I cannot chuſe but love! Oh! George, where is the ſpot, or what the condition I should not think a paradiſe with thee, rather than share a kingdom with Lord Sealand! [Lord Sealand ſings without] Heavens! here comes the hateful wretch—let me endeavour to conceal my agitation!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Emily, my divine creature! how could you be ſo cruel to leave me to mope and grow ſtupid for want of your animating brilliancy and vivacity? 'twas abolutely barbarous, cariſſima mia!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Thoſe are qualities, my lord, I am not happy enough to poſſeſs—but ſurely 'tis impoſſible for Lord Sealand ever to be grave, whoſe animating brilliancy and vivacity would diſpel the gloom of a Greenland winter.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: O you flatterer! but, perhaps, you really think ſo—do you, my adorâble? make me happy by confeſſing it.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I dare ſay your lordſhip has not the leaſt doubt but every body thinks ſo.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Mia bella Signora! I ſee you do—I read it in thoſe eyes, whoſe brightneſs I adore more than the beacons on the South-foreland, when I am returning from Calais in a hazy evening.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Calais! bleſs me, does your lordſhip ever venture ſo far.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Far! O child, that's nothing to me who have even had thoughts of ſailing up the Baltic, or croſſing the Bay of Biſcay, merely to kiſs the empreſs's fair hand, and the pope's great toe! and for a kiſs of thoſe divine lips, I would explore the North-Eaſt-Paſſage! nor think I flatter you, my angel, when I ſwear, that neither flip when I am aboard, or capillaire aſhore, are half ſo dear to me!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: You do me great honour indeed, my lord—but does your lordſhip ever taſte the liquor they call flip?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Taſte it? ay, many a can do I toſs off when I have my watch-coat and trowſers on, and am turning to windward in a briſk gale—but the flip I drink is not like the vile ſtuff commonly ſo call'd, for mine has a moſt delicate flavour, as I always mix it with capillaire.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Well, it is amazing to me what could induce a perſon of your lordſhip's delicacy to venture upon this dangerous amuſement you have lately taken a fancy to.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p:
Why, faith, mia cara! I commenced ſailor merely to avoid the imputation of effeminacy—tho' if we meet with any bad weather at ſea, I immediately retire to my
cabin, and order my pilot, O'Connor, to make for land with all convenient ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! you are perfectly in the right upon my word, my lord.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: But let us change the coarſe indelicate ſubject—I am almoſt tir'd of the ſcheme, and another ſea-ſickneſs will make me drop it, I believe—pray what's become of George? firſt he walk'd off—then you, mia crudel! deſerted us—and ſoon after, Sir Thomas aſk'd me to go with him to ſee the ſick fellow old Goodman was ſpeaking of—as if I had been a phyſician—which I declining, he took away Domine, and left me to indulge in ſoliloquy, juſt as I was concluding our marriage, ma chere! upon honour I have not been treated ſo politely ever ſince I lodg'd with Mynheer Vander-Dunder, the fat Burgo-maſter at Rotterdam.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Concluding our marriage, did you ſay, my lord!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Si, Signora—we were on the very brink of ſettling the preliminaries.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Why, does your lordſhip really ſuppoſe we are to be married?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Is it poſſible you can ſtill make that a queſtion? have not I told you repeatedly I would marry you, my angel?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: But did I ever conſent to marry your lordſhip?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Conſent? egad I don't recollect I ever aſk'd you—on purpoſe to ſpare your confuſion in conſenting, as I am ſure my adorâble will. [taking her by the hand.]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Perhaps your lordſhip may be deceiv'd!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What do I ſee! Emily and Lord Sealand hand in hand! diſtraction! now I am loſt indeed!—but ſhe ſeems averſe to him— why then should I tamely give her up? what is his fortune, title, birth, to me? I have a mind as noble, name as fair, tho' unadorn'd with honours and poſſeſſions!—but I rave— and, if perceiv'd, shall be thought a mean liſt'ner to their converſe. [retiring]

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Ha! George! where have you been, you runaway! in ſome dull arbour I ſuppoſe, poring over your muſty Greek.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I beg pardon, my lord, for this accidental intruſion—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: O you are come quite opportunely to help me ſoften the rigour of this obdurate fair one.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I shall be but an indifferent advocate for love, my lord—it is a language I have not been uſed to talk.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Pho, pho, tell me ſomething monſtrous tender now out of your Ovid, Catullus, Tibullus, or any of the ſoft amorous dogs, ſuited to the extreme violence of my paſſion.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Were I in your place, my lord, I should rather follow their example, than barely repeat their words—they never ſaid any thing to the object of their wishes but what was dictated and inſpir'd by love itſelf!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p:
Ay, that's true—but a rough tar as I am, can't be ſuppos'd to have ſo many
fine expreſſions ready on theſe occaſions, as you ſtudying rhyming ſonneteers; and Lady Sealand, like a tender mother, would never ſuffer me to read or ſtudy much, for fear of ſpoiling my eyes, or making my head ake—come, do now, ſay ſomething monſtrous clever for me— and, in the mean time, (as I fancy my dad, that is to be, is return'd by this) I ſhall go and make you happy, my angel, by concluding the treaty with him.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: My lord!—be not ſo precipitate I intreat your lordſhip!

sp.speaker: L. Scaland.
sp.p: He, I am ſure, will be no leſs proud of the honour of having me for a ſon-in-law, than you, my charmer, are to have me for a huſband—therefore, mia cara ſpoſa! think what day will be moſt agreable to you for the celebration of our nuptials; but, for your own ſake as well as mine, let me intreat you, not to delay our felicity too long!—Addio! (juſqu'au revoir) Addio! mia conteſſa cariſſima! fa, la, la, &c.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Inſolent reptile!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Now had I not a father more attentive to the happineſs than grandeur of his child, I ſhould be completely miſerable!—Oh, Georgel do not think lightly of me for this declaration —I'd ſooner beg with thee, than ſhine in all the ſplendor this wretch's utmoſt power could place me!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Deareſt Emily! think not of me— had providence deſign'd us for each other, my lot in life had been more ſuited to your birth —as it is, tho' I have preſum'd to love, I never cheriſh'd hope—for, not even to gain
thee, Emily! would I abuſe my honour'd patron's confidence! may you, ſweet maid, but meet one more deſerving, while I pray heaven to bleſs and to protect you!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Do not talk ſo—thee only can I love! to thee only will I ever give my hand—I am ſure my father will never force me to marry Sealand, or any one, againſt my will—and perhaps ſome bleſſed moment may incline him to prefer my poor, but virtuous George!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: No more, no more, ſweet Emily! I cannot bear it!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Well! we'll drop the ſubject!—pray, did you ſee Sir Thomas juſt now where you have been?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Where I have been?—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Yes, at the cottage, down the lane— William told me all.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Did he?—but, 'tis no great matter, for the poor woman told me all too, when ſhe return'd from the door, (whither William had taken her to deliver your benefaction)—and likewiſe, that Sir Thomas and my father were talking with him in the lane—whereon, ſuſpecting they were coming there, I quitted the cot immediately, and return'd another way unperceived by them.

div.stage: Sir Thomas Richacre and Dr. Goodman enter.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why, George, where haſt been, lad? I have been ſeeking you.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Sir, I was only— [heſitating]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p:
Come, come, never bluſh at a good action; that's a falſe ſhame, and almoſt as wrong as not to be aſham'd of a bad one: I know
where you have been, and how employed.— Your charity is ſterling, I am ſure, without that too common alloy of oſtentation—and ſo is your's, my dear good girl!—but, pray, have you ſeen nothing of my lord lately, Emily? I expected to have found him here, for when I aſk'd him to go with me, he declin'd it, ſaying he'd walk a turn or two in the garden with you till I return'd.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: He was here juſt now, papa, and after addreſſing me in a moſt inſolent manner, ſaying he was ſure both you, ſir, and myſelf would be proud of his alliance, he left me (as he ſaid) to conclude the treaty with you!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: He did, ha? O, come along, I'll conclude it preſently.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Sir! I hope—dear ſir, [to Dr. Goodman] ſpeak to my papa—for heaven's ſake intercede for me.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Don't alarm yourſelf, dear madam —Sir Thomas will do nothing contrary to your happineſs or inclination, I am certain.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: What's the fool frighten'd at?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: You ſaid, ſir, you'd conclude this hateful treaty!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why, ay, ſo I will—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Then I am loſt indeed! [aſide]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Is it poſſible, ſir! muſt your poor Emily be made a ſacrifice!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Heyday! what the plague's the matter with the girl? I'll conclude it—put an end to it—break it off, you fool!—what can I ſay more to pleaſe you? I'd ſooner marry you to William, or old Metre, than the firſt duke in the land, if he had no better a heart than Lord Sealand.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Then I am happy!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: And I! [aſide]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Ma'am, Lord Sealand ſent me to beg the favour of your ladyſhip to come and play a tune upon your harpſichord till Sir Thomas return'd—which (as you came in the garden way) his lordſhip did not know you was, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: A tune, eh?—ay, ay, we'll go play him a tune directly—I'll ſoon put you out of your pain, I warrant you—for when he hears what muſt be known before you marry any one, and what I believe I ſhall now tell him, I fancy he'll give over the chace of his own accord.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Heavens! what can that be? [aſide to Emily]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: If he does not, you will perhaps think better of him than you do at preſent, and willingly be Lady Sealand.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Never, ſir, I am certain!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Well, well, there's no knowing— we ſhall ſee—go, children, go before us.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Come, my ſweet Emily!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: What can my father mean? [aſide to each other.]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I know not what to think, whether to with or dread an explanation.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Nor I!—but (be it what it may) aſſure yourſelf, dear George, I never will be Lady Sealand!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: I believe, my good old friend, no better time than now for the diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: I think ſo too, dear ſir—heaven proſper the event!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Shall ſhe be Sealand's if he holds his purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: By no means, ſir! and heaven avert, hereſelf ſhould ever wiſh it!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ay, ſo ſay I—but to be a counteſs is perhaps an almoſt irreſiſtable temptation!

div.stage: Exeunt Sir Thomas Richacre and Dr. Goodman. Patty remains.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: By gemini, I am in great hopes ſhe'll have my lord! and if ſhe does, I think I ſtand no bad chance of having young Mr. Goodman! oh, lud! the very thoughts of it make me almoſt out of my wits!—but, hang this college-education —he ſeems ſo very baſhful, I am afraid he'll never have courage to aſk one the queſtion downright—what ſhall I do then?— why, I don't know any other way than this— if he can't get the better of his modeſty, and aſk me, I muſt e'en try if I can't conquer mine, and aſk him!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Ecod, here ſhe be!—I've found the little baggage at laſt—why, Patty, love! I thought I'd loſt you—never ſtir if I ha'n't look'd up and down for you like bewitch'd— odſbodikins! I'm glad I ha' found you.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: [coldly] Why, did you want any thing, William?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p:
Want any thing, Patty! no, not I —nothing but to ſee thee, cauſe you know you was a little frumpiſh afore dinner; and I 'a'n't
been eaſy in my mind ever ſince—come, Patty, won't you make it up?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Make what up, Mr. William? I don't know that we have had any difference— you have done nothing to offend me, and I have no reaſon to ſuppoſe I have ſaid or done any thing to affront you.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Me! no, lord love your dear heart! I never was angry with you two minutes together in my life—ſo let's kiſs and friends—

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Kiſs!—Pray, Mr. William, keep your diſtance—I don't know what behaviour of mine can have caus'd you to forget yourſelf ſo much.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Why, Patty, you be only joking ſure—come, gi' us a buſs, you little croſs-patch you.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Why, William, you have been drinking ſure, or you could never be ſo bold.

sp.speaker: William,
sp.p: Drinking, Patty!—I don't know what you mean by ſuch an inſinivation as that —I believe (ay, and you knows it too as well as I do) there ben't a ſoberer lad in all the pariſh—drinking!—lord help me!—if I have ſwallow'd a drop or a crumb of any thing ſince breakfaſt, but one horn of ale, and a bit of meat as big as my three fingers, I'm a drunkard and a glutton into the bargain! and I'd as lief be thought a thief as either—ſo you ſhou'd not ſay that of me, Patty!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Mr. William, I ſaid nothing about your eating—it's nothing to me what you eat, or drink either—what do you think I care? or whether you ever eat or drink again or not!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Indeed!—if I thought you was in earneſt, Patty, I don't think I ever ſhould!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Well, that's none of my buſineſs, you know—I don't concern myſelf about inferior ſervants!—all I deſire of you is, that you will not make ſo free with me for the future as you have had the confidence to do lately, for I am determin'd I won't put up with it!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Why, I am ſure you can't ſay I ever behav'd uncivil to you, Patty—and if ſo be I have made bold to tell you I lov'd you, I ſaid nought but truth—ay, and you have ſaid as much to me more than once, for all you're ſo ſcornful now.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: I ſay I lov'd you? no, William!—I own I had a ſort of friendſhip for you, becauſe I thought you an honeſt young man and ſo forth—but, love? O, no, William! I am very ſorry you miſtook my civility—I never had ſuch a thought I aſſure you—I have very different views!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Patty!—eh?—what do you ſay?— don't you go to—dear Patty!—odrabbit it! my heart's ſo full I can't ſpeak to her—and, if I could help it, I'd never ſpeak to her again!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: I ſhould be very glad of it—and I deſire, nay, I inſiſt upon it, that you never offer to open your lips to me again; for if you do I ſha'n't anſwer you, and ſo, your ſervant!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Stay, Patty—one word more before we break off our courtſhip—for a courtſhip it has been, ſay what you will—ay, and a tender one too! or elſe when I ſet off for Oxford ſo long ago with Maſter George—

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: George! you make very free with your betters methinks—it might be Mr. Goodman in your mouth.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Ay, bleſs his dear ſoul! there's no name too kind for him—but, as I was going to ſay—if ſo be you was not in love with me, as well as I in love with you, why did you break this bit of gold with me, which I have worn next my heart ever ſince? but I'll be hang'd if I wear it any longer—come off, rot thee!—there, there's your keep-ſake, your love-token again! and you're a falſe-hearted girl!— and if you'll promiſe never to ſpeak to me again, I never will to you while I have breath in my body!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: I believe there's no great need of promiſing on my ſide, I ſhan't be the firſt to break the ſilence, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Why then fare thee well, Patty! my heart's my own again!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Ay, and a good riddance! take up with a footman indeed, when I have ſuch a proſpect of being a gentlewoman—I wonder who'd be fool then! I'm ſure I won't be ſuch a one, and ſo your ſervant, Mr. William!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: And your ſervant, Mrs. Patt! if you go to that—a murrain take her for a ſcornful young toad! [bawls after her] I don't care a braſs thimble for you! no nor a pin's point! —and you're a baſe, deceitful, falſe-hearted— [burſts out a crying] odrabbit it! I don't think I ſhall get the better of this the longeſt day I have to live!

div.head: ACT III. Scene, the Summer-houſe.—Lord Sealand, Sir Thomas Richacre, Doctor Goodman, George, and Emily, diſcovered ſeated.

sp.speaker: LORD SEALAND.
sp.p: AND now the decks are clear'd of the tea equipage, if you pleaſe, Sir Thomas, we'll reſume our topic.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: With all my heart, my lord; the ſooner we come to the point the better.

sp.speaker: George,
sp.p: [riſing] You have ſome private buſineſs with his lordſhip, I believe, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: O no, there are no ſecrets going forward, George; at leaſt, none that are to remain ſo—you need not ſtir, boy.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: With your leave, ſir, I'll take a turn or two in the garden the while— [aſide] I dread the event, nor dare I ſtay to hear it— heaven preſerve you, my dear—loſt Emily!

sp.speaker: Lord Sealand.
sp.p: Now, ſir, if you pleaſe—for I wait with as much impatience as a becalm'd veſſel for a briſk gale to drive her ſafe into port.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: A briſk gale quotha! ecod, I have a notion there will blow ſuch a breeze preſently as will go near to overſet you, my lord —or that your veſſel, not being heart of oak, will ſpring a leak; for our diſcourſe will take a turn you little think of.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Dear papa, permit me to retire! [riſing]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: By no means, my dear—there is a particular reaſon why you ſhould be preſent, otherwiſe indeed it might be deem'd a ſoleciſm in forms—but, don't be alarm'd, for I have not the moſt diſtant idea that this will come to any thing.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: What a ſavage!—O, ſir, we'll diſpenſe with a little form—to the point, if you pleaſe, Lady Sealand and I are all attention.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [aſide] Inſolent and cruel!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: To begin then—your lordſhip hath addreſs'd this young woman?—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: This angel! this goddeſs whom I adore!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Plain Engliſh, if you pleaſe, my lord—and demanded her of me in marriage? —pray now, if I may be ſo bold, what is your lordſhip's motive for it?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: What can it be but the moſt ardent paſſon?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: For her?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: For her! who elſe, dear ſir, could I poſſibly—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Say rather, what elſe?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p:
Why, your lordſhip being (no doubt) pretty well inform'd of the value of my rent-roll; is that, or this
[taking Emily by the hand] the goddeſs you adore?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: This is mighty ſtrange, Sir Thomas—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p:
No offence I hope, my lord— but, as I muſt be aſſur'd that whoever marries her has no other motive than a real, a diſintereſted affection for herſelf; this is the ſingle
queſtion, upon your anſwer to which depends the event.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Propoſe it, dear ſir, propoſe it.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: If, inſtead of being daughter to a baronet, and heireſs to a very conſiderable eſtate, ſhe had no other recommendation or endowment than her own beauty and virtue, would you, my lord, or would you not, raiſe her to the rank of Lady Sealand?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Is it poſſible, ſir, you can have a doubt of it? what is the condition I wou'd not raiſe her from!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Emily, my dear, come hither—I am going to loſe thee, my little cherub!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Sir! is it poſſible!—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: The time is come, ſweet child, I muſt reſign thee!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [to Dr. Goodman] Good ſir, ſupport me—I cannot—oh! [faints]

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: [to Sir Thomas] Dear ſir, her ſpirits are quite overcome—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Don't be alarm'd, gentlemen;— nothing but the mauvaiſe honte uſual on theſe occaſions—or perhaps the exceſs of joy may have been too powerful for her—where the devil is my eau-de-luce?—look up, cariſſima mia ſpoſa!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [reviving] O my dear father!—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: One kiſs, ſweet girl! and I reſign that name—for, I am not your father!—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Gracious heaven!—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: What do you ſay, Sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: I am not her father—and now, my lord, determine—here ſhe is, as rich in perſonal and mental gifts, as ſhe is poor in fortune, for ſhe has none!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: The devil! what a narrow eſcape! I had like to have weigh'd anchor, and hoiſted ſale for that damn'd long round-the-world-voy-age of matrimony, in a veſſel without either ballaſt or proviſion! [aſide]—Why, undoubtedly, Sir Thomas, fortune was my leaſt conſideration—but, if the young lady is not your daughter, 'tis proper I ſhould firſt know who is her father—it may be ſomebody whoſe family it would be improper for me to marry into.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [kneeling to Sir Thomas] Moſt honour'd ſir!—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Riſe, riſe, my dear! you muſt kneel no more to me! [raiſing her]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Where ſhall I kneel? where ſeek my father, if you are not!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Turn hither, my heart's darling! and behold him—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Did I hear right? are you, ſir, are you my father!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: I am! I am! [embracing her] I have endur'd a long conſtraint, but at length am free to boaſt—I am your father!—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Heyday! here's a turn! the wind has chop'd about with a vengeance—one minute ſouth, and the next due north as ever it can blow.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [to Sir Thom.] O ſir, forgive me, nor think this an ill return for your paternal goodneſs.—I love—I honour you moſt highly, ſir, and ever muſt revere you! but nature pleads moſt ſtrongly in my breaſt—I love my father too! [kneeling to Dr. Goodman, who raiſes and embraces her]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why that's my brave girl! I never yet knew half your goodneſs, and love you (if poſſible) better now than ever.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Well, upon honour, this is the moſt whimſical adventure I ever met with— what, in the name of oddity, Sir Thomas, could induce you to bring up the young gentlewoman as your's?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: That's my concern, my lord—I had my reaſons for it, which time perhaps may ſhew—the only queſtion neceſſary at preſent is, whether (if ſhe is willing) you will, or will not, marry her?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: A moment's pauſe, I beg, Sir Thomas—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Pho, pho, come—ſpeak boldly, man—was it the girl, or the eſtate you ador'd? in plain engliſh, are you a man of honour, or are you a—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Sir Thomas—you are really ſo precipitate—I beg the indulgence of a few moments reflection—I'll—think a little, madam, and let you know my determination preſently—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: My lord, you need not trouble yourſelf to think about it; for reſt aſſur'd, that (fall'n as you may think me) nothing can induce me ever to be your lordſhip's!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: [aſide] I never met with ſuch a curſed embarras before!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! ſo much for modern love!—Emily, you have loſt your counteſsſhip, my dear—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: His refuſal has made me happy, ſir, beyond expreſſion—and ſo I flatter myſelf it will make George—ha!—George!—merciful heaven! the thought occur'd not 'till this moment—he is my brother!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: And I fancy you had conceiv'd more than a ſiſterly affection for him—eh, Emily?—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I had indeed, ſir! for, to confeſs what now is needleſs to conceal, I lov'd him ardently; and (ignorant of my birth) had I been miſtreſs of the world, he muſt have ſhar'd it with me, or I had been a beggar!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ay, I thought as much—well, well, time's a good phyſician, and cures more ills than half the doctors living—it will wear off, I warrant you—no ſign of my lord weathercock's turning about again? no!—I believe it's in vain to expect him—we had better ſeek for George, and inform him of what has paſs'd.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Come, my delight! my only pride! my ſweet child, come—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Excuſe me a little, my dear father! I'll follow you directly—I will but dry theſ • tears and—oh! [in a burſt of grief.]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Pho, pho, never take on ſo about it, Emily—you ſha'n't go without a huſband yet, if there's one in the kingdom that deſerves you—what ſay you to a Richacre, my girl?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Oh, ſir, that I reſpect, revere and love you with a moſt filial affection, I think you do not boubt—but—moſt honour'd ſir! my other parent!—let me ſtop there—my heart's too
full!—be not offended, ſir—I can no more— Oh, George! George!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Well, well, we'll talk no more about it at preſent—but upon my word you muſt not remain ſingle, Emily—for, to tell you the truth, I ſhould have been ſadly baulk'd, and my whole ſcheme fruſtrated, had my lord behav'd otherwiſe; as I have all along had hopes (which I flatter myſelf will yet be accompliſh'd) of prevailing on you to accept for ever that name you have ſo long honour'd by the uſing!—come along, my old friend— friend, quotha! ecod, who knows how nearly we may be related ſoon! eh?—ha, ha, ha!

div.stage: Exit Sir Thomas Richacre and Dr. Goodman.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: What a reverſe of fate! how am I bereft of all my fond, vain hopes of happineſs and love!—had I been reduc'd to the moſt abject poverty—had I loſt him I thought my father, and found no other—had every calamity our woe-fill'd lives are fraught with, but this, at once beſel me, I had ſtill been happy; but now, (oh, George! oh, brother!) I am ſunk ten thouſand times more deep than wretch e'er plung'd before!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Alone, Emily? where are Sir Thomas and my father? I ſaw my lord go down the yew-tree walk, ſo thinking the conference over, I return'd to learn how it had ended— what was th' important ſecret on which ſo much depended?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh, George!—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: How! weeping! then I know enough, and now am nothing! O fortune! title! how powerful are your charms that can betray goodneſs itſelf and make it err!

sp.speaker: Emily,
sp.p: Forbear, forbear!—you know not why I grieve—you can't conceive the exquiſite diſtreſs of my preſent ſituation!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Not conceive how dreadful to be given to thoſe we hate, as I am perſuaded you do Sealand?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh, George, there now needs no diſguiſe—the doom irrevocable's paſt! did you indeed e'er love me?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Love you! do I breathe? do I exiſt?—could I, but to love you!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Then we both are truly wretched!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: We are indeed! but if, as I have fondly thought, our love was mutual, how doubly wretched is your fate—doom'd thus to marry one that you deteſt!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No, that's not my grief—'thank heaven he has refus'd me.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Refus'd you!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: You will not wonder when I can tell you why—Sir Thomas Richacre—is—not my father! [burſting into tears]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Not your father! amazing—yet moſt happy ſound! then I may hope—and the firſt gleam I ever knew now ſhoots into my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No, there is no hope—an eternal barrier is fix'd between us! for you are—I cannot ſpeak it!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I am—gracious heaven!—what?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: My brother!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Your brother!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: My dear, dear brother!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Support me, or I fall!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: With my very life! [weeping and embracing him]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: So, ſo! here's fine work going forward—kiſſing and hugging at a rare rate! it's more than he ever offer'd to me!—by jingo, I don't half like this; ſhe'll never have my lord, nor I him, if they go on thus—it's well I did not buy the lottery-ticket, ſeeing how matters are going! [aſide]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Look up, dear George!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Dear George! lord, how loving we are! [aſide]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Am I indeed ſo near to you?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Yes, you can't be much nearer, I think! in her very arms! how near wou'd you be, I wonder! [aſide]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Your brother!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: What! [aſide]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Then there is no hope indeed!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: No, I hope not—but, what can this mean? [aſide]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Patty!—how long have you been here?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: I am but this moment come, madam —Sir Thomas ſent me to deſire your ladyſhip—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: O Patty, you muſt forget thoſe words —I am no lady now—

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: No ma'am! how ſo?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
No longer heireſs to a ſplendid fortune, but ſiſter to this much lov'd youth—the
virtues of a reverend parent muſt be now our joint inheritance!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: But to what purpoſe, Emily, was you bred up as daughter to Sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: He told Lord Sealand there was a reaſon for it, which time perhaps would ſhew— and, in addition to my miſery, after my lord had left us, ſaid he was pleas'd at his refuſal of me; having all along intended I ſhould ſtill keep the name of Richacre—meaning, no doubt, with my concurrence, to marry me himſelf!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing! yet that accounts for all.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Good gracious! I hardly know how to believe all this—I am afraid ſhe's only joking [aſide]—lord, ma'am, I hope you an't ſerious all this time—are n't you Sir Thomas's daughter indeed?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No, Patty, you have loſt your miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: [aſide] I have found a huſband in the ſtead tho', and that's ten times better!—but I muſt ſeem ſorry—Dear heart, ma'am, I am vaſtly concern'd to hear this, for you was very good to me, and I muſt never expect to have ſo many nice cloaths given me again, unleſs his worſhip ſhould really be ſo kind as to marry you himſelf, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Happy, happy girl! 'would I had no greater grief than thine!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p:
Why, to be ſure, ma'am, the black ox has trod upon your foot a little, as the ſaying is—and one misfortune ſeldom comes alone, as the other ſaying is—you have been very unlucky indeed, ma'am, to loſe a great fortune,
and your ſweetheart too, both at once—for I do verily believe you had a kindneſs for Mr. Goodman before you knew he was your brother—but now that's all over.— [aſide] 'Thank my kind ſtars! and I ſhall be Mrs. Goodman as ſure as fate!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: No, Patty, it is not all over!—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Nor will be but with life!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Lord, ma'am! why ſure you wou'd not love your own brother!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Not love him! who ſhall debar me that?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Nay, ma'am, I only juſt ſpoke—for brothers and ſiſters did formerly marry I grant, or the world could not have been peopled— but that's quite out of faſhion now, you know, ma'am—unleſs indeed you had been romancatholic-papiſhes, and were lucky enough to be Sir Thomas's children inſtead of Dr. Goodman's; becauſe I have heard ſay, if people have but money enough, the pope will grant a —compenſation—I think they call it, or ſome ſuch hard name, (I ſuppoſe it means an act of parliament) for a man to marry his own grandmother! but indeed, ma'am, if I was you, I'd think no more of my brother, but take Sir Thomas at his word, and marry my father— that is, as he is not your father.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Prithee have done, Patty; I am not yet reconcil'd enough unto my fate, to bear this ill-tim'd mirth—I might, nay, perhaps I ſhall, find refuge in a cloyſter, and dedicate my future wretched life to heaven!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
No, Emily! 'tis I ſhould be ſequeſtered from the world; you have been taught to look for happineſs, and, by accepting of Sir
Thomas's moſt worthy hand and noble fortune, yet may find it.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Impoſſible! oh, name it not again— never will I baſely take the hand and fortune I cannot in return for give my heart!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Forgive me, deareſt maid! nor think I had any view in what I ſaid, but your repoſe and welfare; for what little patrimony my honour'd father may have gather'd for us both, ſhall now be wholly yours; as I will immediately enter into holy orders, devote my life to a religious celibacy, nor ever think again of love or womankind!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: O goodneſs heart! that will be a great pity, ſir; for there's many a pretty girl, I dare ſay, would be proud to have you.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Come, my dear brother! let us attend Sir Thomas and our father, I promis'd to follow them directly.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Our father! oh, Emily—my ſiſter! —I cannot bear the thought—it ſhocks—it overpow'rs—it mads me!—my ſweet Emily —go you, while I endeavour to compoſe this agitation of my ſpirits before I ſee them.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: May heaven reſtore you to your peace of mind!—but mine—is loſt for ever!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: [after ſome little pauſe] Sir,—ſir,—ſir!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: What do you ſay, child? [peeviſhly]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p:
Why, ſir,—I hope you won't be angry at ſuch a ſimple girl as me offering to adviſe you—but really I would not have you think of living ſingle; for to my certain knowledge, there is a girl in the world, ay, and a good
pretty girl too, that's not far off, would be very ſorry you ſhou'd die a batchelor.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Which I moſt ſurely ſhall! [ſighing]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Mercy forbid, ſir!—for indeed you are a very pretty gentleman! and ſeeing as how you and your ſiſter can't conveniently come together, if I was in your place, I ſhou'd look about me a little—and if ſuch a thing was to happen, that you even took a fancy to me, ſir, I don't think I could find in my heart to be cruel to you—and tho' I am not your equals, you might go farther and fare worſe— for I have a little money by me, and a proſpect of getting a very large ſum ſoon—and you know, ſir, I am a ſort of an heireſs (as I may call it) beſides, and I dare ſay my father has ſav'd ſomething worth having. [ſhe ſtands curtſying and ſimpering to him]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: How this ſilly girl torments me! I had better check her, or the giddy creature may ſuppoſe I know not what—I thank you, Patty, for your good will to me,—
