sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Thank you, Patty! O gemini, I believe he'll come to at laſt. [aſide]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: But hope you'll not deceive yourſelf into what might hereafter prove a trouble to you.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: No indeed, ſir, it never would—ſo far from it, every thing I did for you wou'd be a pleaſure to me!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Still you miſtake me, my good girl—

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Good girl! O the dear ſoul, I ſhall have him as ſure as a gun! [aſide] No, indeed, ſir, I don't—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Pray hear me without interruption—

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, that I will [curtſying] for, to be ſure, I cou'd hear you talk for ever!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I am afraid you have conceiv'd ſomething like love for me—

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Like love? indeed, ſir, if a poor baſhful girl muſt ſpeak out—it's love in downright earneſt! [curtſying very low]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Pray don't interrupt me—you have entertain'd, I ſay, a partiality for me you miſtake for love, and which a return to might poſſibly confirm in you; but, as that can never be, I intreat you, for your own repoſe, in time to check it, and never think again of what is impoſſible!—Oh, love! thou tyrant o'er the heart, how contradictory are thy decrees!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Impoſſible! why is it impoſſible? ſure I am not his fiſter too—lord, lord! that any body ſhould ſtand ſo in their own light!— well—it don't ſignify fretting about it—if I can't have him, I muſt have ſomebody elſe?— and, as he won't marry me, I think I'll e'en behave kinder to poor William, for I'm ſure he loves me dearly—and if I can but coax him to forget how I uſed him to day, and aſk me the queſtion (as he often has before) again, if I don't have him, I'll be whipt!—as I live, here he comes, and a likely lad he is as any in the pariſh—George Goodman, with all his airs, an't half ſo handſome.—I'll pretend not to ſee him, to try if he'll break his reſolution and ſpeak firſt.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Ay, there ſhe ſtands, a ſulky thing! what can have made the little puſs ſo plaguy croſs-grain'd to day?—ſhe won't take a bit of notice of me—a ſtubborn young baggage! and I'll be hang'd if I ſpeak to her firſt—if I can help it! [ſeemingly going]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Not one word, by jingo!—if I don't take care I ſhall loſe him too—ſince he won't ſpeak, I muſt! ſo, come down proud ſtomach! —William!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Did you call, Mrs. Patty?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Ay, William,—why you paſs by a body as if you had never ſeen one before.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Why, Mrs. Patty, I be unwilling to anger any one—and the laſt time we parted, you know you bid me never ſpeak to you again; ſo I was trying to pleaſe you that way —thof it almoſt breaks my heart! but if it kill'd me outright, I ſhou'd not care, if it did but pleaſure you, Patty! [half crying]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Lord, William! why you did not think I was in right earneſt, did you?— ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Eh!—he, he, he! why, wa'n't you Patty? [wiping his eyes while he laughs]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Wa'n't I! why no, I tell you—I only did it to try you a little—ha, ha, ha!—that was all.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Was that all? lord, lord, if I cou'd not ha'ſworn you was in downright earneſt! for you have look'd all day long as if you cou'd eat me with a grain of ſalt!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: But I cou'd not tho', William—for I have too great a regard for you to hurt a hair of your head.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Have you indeed?—well now, that is kind to tell it me!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: I ſhould be very ungrateful to behave otherwiſe than kind to you, William, who have always profeſt ſo much love to me—nay, more than once even aſk'd me to marry you.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Ay, more than twenty times, Patty —and, if you were but willing, I'd axe your father leave to get Mr. Liturgy, our curate, to publiſh the banns for us next ſabbath; and, as ſoon as ever we were out-ax'd, I'd marry you, and love you to my dying day!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: I thank you kindly, William, for your offer—but, had not we better wait a few years longer, 'till we have ſav'd a little to begin the world with; as I don't imagine you are much richer than myſelf.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Pho, never heed riches, Patty— it's none but thoſe who have too much already, that marry for the lucre of gain!—not that I be poor neither—laſt wages, I gave my father to ſave for me, made (with what he had before of mine) forty-four pounds, twelve ſhillings and fix-pence—that is, in even money, forty-two golden guineas and a half—ſo, you ſee, Patty, I be ſomebody, and ha' gotten a good round ſum to begin the world—but, if we had not a ſixpenny-piece between us, a young couple that have health and limbs to work, a good heart, and a ſound conſcience, have enough to begin twenty worlds!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p:
That's very true, William—and I don't think there's a heartier young couple in
the county than we are—beſides, I have a very handſome ſum of money by me too, and a power of good cloaths Miſs Emily gave me—

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Well then, Patty, ſhall us put what little we have together, and make a match on't, eh?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Indeed, William, I don't know what to ſay to it—

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Come, never be faint-hearted—nor ſtand ſhilly-ſhally about it, you ſimple tony— [kiſſing her]

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Bleſs my eyeſight! what do I ſee? I hope the boy hath no unchaſte purpoſe!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: You know, Patty, I do love you dearly—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: But honeſtly I truſt—

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: And if you'll only ſay the word—

sp.speaker: Meltre.
sp.p: Goodlack, I am terrified!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: I'll go buy a ring directly.—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Oh!—I am ſatisfied!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: I do know the ſize of this dear finger to a tittle—and it ſhall be as heavy as your heart can wiſh.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: No, heavy rings are not the faſhion now—let it be a light one, Willy.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Now then, my dear Patt, you be my own for ever and ever! [kiſſing and hugging her]

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: He, he, he! their amorous parley is wond'rous pretty, I do proteſt!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Well, I vow, Billy, you have a moſt bewitching tongue, and have quite won my heart!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: He, he! that's pure!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: But you muſt aſk my father's leave, for I would not do ſuch a thing without his bleſſing for ever ſo much.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Thou art a dutiful good child, and heaven I hope will bleſs and proſper you! [ſtill aſide]

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Why you know, Patty, I mention'd that before, and I'll go directly and tell un the whole ſtory—odsfleſh! here he is, as ſure as a gun!—well, how lucky this be!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Heyday! what hath exhilarated thee ſo, William?—thou lookeſt as merry and happy!—

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Merry and happy! ay, that I be— and hilarated too, as you call it, I believe; for, ecod! I hardly know whether I ſtand upon my head or my heels!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Why?—what hath pleaſed thee ſo overmuch?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: What I do hope will not diſpleaſe you, or we ſhall be all in a ſad quandary.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Lord, I am ſo aſham'd, I can't look my father in the face. [aſide]

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: What is all this about?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Why, fir,—I—that is, Patty and I, if—you—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Patty, and I, if—you! what? what? —why doſt not ſpeak out?—doſt thou know, Martha, what it is he lacketh?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: I believe, father, I partly gueſs—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Well, what is it?—

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Why don't you tell my father, Mr. William?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: No, do you, Patty— [ſhifting each other to Metre]

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Come, come, ſpeak out boldly, lad! —faint heart never won fair lady.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Ecod, you've hit it! for—you muſt know, ſir,—Patty being in love with me— that is—I being in love with ſhe I mean—if ſo be you were but willing, we ſhou'd be main proud to become man and wife together!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Is this true, Martha?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, father! [bluſhing and curtſying]

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Yes, if you pleaſe, fa her! [bowing]

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Why, William, as I have often told thee before, I believe thou art a very honeſt good lad—but, in troth, ye are both full young.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: No indeed we a'n't, father!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: 'Twould be only loſing time to ſtay any longer—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Well, I will take it into ſerious cogitation—as you will be under my eye—I think—I ſhall not oppoſe your virtuous inclinations, but will moſt humbly ſolicit the ſanction and permiſſion of his reverence and Sir Thomas, which I am prone to think, at my intreaty, will not be withheld.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: No, I hope not!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: And then, father, when I am Patty's ſpouſe, I'll keep the bible you ſaid to day you'd give me as choice as old gold, to write the names of all our children in; if ſo be that we increaſe and multiply, which I do hope and pray to heaven we may, Patty!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Ay, and ſo do I, I am ſure, William!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: [taking one of them in each hand] Never did I unto any prayer more fervently ejaculate Amen!
All three go off repeating—Amen!

div.head: ACT IV. Scene, a retired Part of the Garden.

sp.speaker: EMILY.
sp.p: WHY do you perſiſt, my lord, in detaining me thus rudely, and prevent my returning to the houſe? pray let me paſs, my lord—I deſire you'd leave me!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Leave you? impoſſible, my angelic creature! I exiſt but in your preſence!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: That your lordſhip's exiſtence has no ſort of dependance upon me, I have had a moſt convincing proof.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: How can you be ſo cruel, my adorable! have I not declared the moſt ardent paſſion for you? am I not now confirming it? what can I ſay or you deſire more?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Indeed, my lord, I never thought to hear ſuch words as theſe from you again—the effect Sir Thomas's explanation had upon your lordſhip, made me conclude—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: O, crudel! can you ſuppoſe I love you more or leſs, my charmer, for being daughter to this gentleman or that? no—my love is (as Sir Thomas wiſh'd it) intirely perſonal, and in poſſeſſing you, my angel, I aſk no more!—bravo, Sealand! [aſide]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: How have I been deceived! I bluſh to think how much I have wrong'd this generous man! [aſide]

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Why do you turn away, ma chére? why avoid me? ſure I deſerve a better treatment—I, that am waiting to receive, and place you in a ſtate of affluence ſuperior to that in which you have been bred, and from which you are ſo unexpectedly fall'n—but grieve not at that, for in my arms you'll find ſafe harbour from all the ſtorms of fortune!— Pretty and poetical that! I don't think Ovid, or any of the love-ſick tribe, ever ſaid a better thing. [aſide]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: O my lord! pardon me, I beſeech you, for having thought of you ſo unworthily —I feel the warmeſt gratitude for this ſo generous a declaration, but cannot profit by it.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Say not ſo, my charmer—you know not half the good that waits on you and yours—your father ſhall be rais'd as high as I have power or intereſt to advance him—your brother too—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Ah, my poor George!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: He ſhall be poor no longer— I'll give him a living, buy him a commiſſion —or place him to his wiſh in whatever ſtile of life he may prefer—ſay but you will be mine—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: What is there elſe I wou'd not do to ſerve my father and too-much-lov'd brother! and teſtify my gratitude, and the great reſpect I now have for your lordſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p:
No more, no more; prithee, my charming angel, have done with gratitude, reſpect, and all ſuch cold unanimated expreſſions—love is all I require; give me but that, and all the joys and luxuries of life attend
you—well ſaid again, Sealand! egad, this love makes a man talk divinely! [aſide]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh, ſir! think not of a wretched creature, who ne'er can taſte of joy again!— were you, if poſſible, more noble, good and generous than I now find you—were you at once the greateſt and the beſt of human kind—ſo indelible is the impreſſion (tho' ever unattainable the object it is made by!) on my afflicted heart, I could not marry with your lordſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Ha? what!—marry? O no, my dear, I did not mean that!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: My lord!—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: I love you, my divine creature, to adoration, almoſt diſtraction—every thing but matrimony—and that, oh, that wou'd be downright madneſs indeed! non, non, mia cara ſignora! that's quite out of the queſtion now —your planks are ſtarted! and, from a veſſel of burthen richly freighted, that has loſt her cargo in a ſtorm, you muſt now be cut down to a pleaſure-boat!—no had metaphor that for a ſailor—'gad, I think I ſhine to day! [aſide]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Good heaven! what can your lordſhip mean?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Mean, my charmer? mean that I adore you!—that you ſhall be as happy as love and gold can make you—ſhall command my heart and ſhare my fortune—any thing but marriage; and that your own good ſenſe muſt tell you is now impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: At length I awake—my dream of honour, generoſity, reſpect, and gratitude is now no more—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand,
sp.p:
But when your father and George are inform'd of what I propoſe for their advancement,
as well as for your own, I am ſure they will readily—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Stop your licentious tongue, abandon'd wretch! are you not content with this moſt baſe attempt on me, but muſt my pious father and moſt virtuous brother be your ſacrifices too! muſt they partake and countenance ſuch guilt! oh, ſhame, ſhame! diſgrace and ſcandal to your dignity and birth!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Heyday! what is all this? you can't be ſerious ſure, child, in rejecting ſo genteel an offer?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Sweet heaven look down with pity on me! the meaſure of my woes was full before—now it o'erflows!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Why, my dear, you have really made a very fine progreſs in the ſmall time you have known yourſelf to be the parſon's daughter —you both preach and pray moſt divinely upon my ſoul!—but we'll leave ſuch dull ſtuff at preſent to thoſe who know no better how to employ themſelves—come, my Venus! let us retire to yonder moſſy couch; where Paphian, Cyprian, and Citherêan boughs entwine to form a ſhade for love!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Unhand me, ſir!—how do you dare inſult me thus!—be aſſur'd, altho' Sir Thomas is not my father, he will reſent this outrage.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: O fie! how can you be ſo illbred, my dear creature, and want ſo much courting to your own happineſs? Come—I am certain you'll not be angry at a little gentle violence—let me thus force my angel to be kind!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: For honour's ſake, my lord, forbear! pity my diſtreſs'd condition, bereft of fortune, love, almoſt of life! nor with unmanly violence add infamy to my already inſupportable afflictions!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: 'Tis all in vain—you are a charming girl, I love you, the place is bien commode! and—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: On my knees I beg!—think what diſtraction a reverend parent and a tender brother both muſt feel for my undoing! and, with a nobleneſs ſuited to your birth, my lord! forego the advantage you now have o'er my defenceleſs ſituation, and quit your horrid purpoſe!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Ridiculous! to ſuppoſe I'd miſs this golden opportunity—no, no!—comply therefore, my charmer! and ſpare me the diſagreeable neceſſity of compelling you—you won't, eh? why then we muſt have a fair trial of who is ſtrongeſt—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Help, help, ſweet heaven! reſcue a helpleſs creature from deſtruction! oh, ſave me from diſhonour and perdition!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: You may as well be ſilent, child, for we are far enough from the houſe—nobody hears you—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Yes, villain, I do!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And ſo has heaven!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Pox take him! is he here?—I wiſh he was at Oxford again with all my ſoul. [aſide]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: O my dear brother! my protector! my guardian angel!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: My ſiſter! my ſweet innocence!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: O rot you both! I have got into a bleſſed ſcrape here—I wiſh I was in the Bay of Biſcay with all my heart! [aſide]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Cruel inſulter! to trample on a wretch juſt fall'n to earth!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: How did you dare, ſir—if you had no other ſenſe of guilt—how did you dare to violate the laws of hoſpitality thus groſsly!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Oh, now you are going to preach —very good—proceed, ſir—I am all attention! and muſt edify, no doubt, as I ſhall be finely lectur'd (I ſuppoſe) between you.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Inſenſible villain! dead to every feeling of ſhame, remorſe, of honour or humanity!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Sir, your moſt obedient!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: But, my lord! tho' you did not think this poor girl worthy to be your wife, remember ſhe is my ſiſter, and not to be diſhonour'd by the moſt exalted ruffian!—for your preſent ſafety be thankful we are unarm'd; elſe, in the cauſe of injur'd virtue, I ſhould forget there was a female preſent, and puniſh your atrocious villainy on the ſpot!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Why really, ſir, if you are certain of victory before the encounter, I think it full as well indeed that we are unarm'd!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: My dear George, contain yourſelf— oh!—I can ſcarce ſtand—pray lead me in!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Lean on me, my ſweet ſiſter, and fear nothing! have a care, ſir, how we meet again, it may be fatal to you!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Be calm, my brother! my deliverer!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Fear nothing, deareſt!—bear up— bear up! he muſt be more than man who injures you while I am by, and leſs than man who could at any time attempt it!
[looking ſcornfully on L. Sealand]

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Pox take you for an ignorant, impertinent, meddleſome puppy, I ſay!—here am I to loſe a fine girl, becauſe her ſtupid brother knows ſo little of the world—rot him!— but I'll not drop the affair here I am determined—let me conſider—um!—ay faith, the very thing! then ſhe may ſquall 'till ſhe's hoarſe again, and I need not apprehend a ſecond interruption—my French ſcoundrel ſhall about it inſtantly. [going]—Hold—what noiſe is that?—

div.stage: [La Poudre and Robert croſs the back of the ſtage, talking and laughing.]

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Apropos! yonder is the very fellow I want—La Poudre! La Poudre!

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Eſt ce que your lorſhip pleſe to vant a me?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Yes, I do pleaſe to vant a you, you puppy; come hither—

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Je ſuis bien aiſe—I ver much glad den I happen to valk a dis vay—ſave a your lorſhip de peine to ſend for me.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Hold your damn'd Babel of a tongue, and mind what I ſay.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: I am not ſay von vard, mi lor— I am dumb.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: I wiſh you was with all my ſoul—at leaſt for the preſent—

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Fort bien, my lor—I ſhall not open my mous—je ne dirai pas un mot—not von vard I vil ſpeak.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Then ceaſe that confuſion of languages, you damn'd French chattering raſcal, and hear me!

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: I hear a your lorſhip parfaitement bien, and ſo may de whole pariſhe, ma foi!— you talk a ſo loud, I hear you if I was two tree mile off—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Ha! egad the puppy ſays true— and that's not altogether ſo proper at preſent— who was that with you?

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Your lorſhip coaſhaman, Robert.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: That's lucky, by Jupiter! call the ſurly ſavage hither.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: I vil, my lor—ici!—Robert! Robert!—come ſpeak a mi lor—courez, courez, plus vite! for vy you not make a great haſte, you ſurly ſauvage!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Do you want me, my lord?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Yes, Robert; put the horſes to directly.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I can't juſt yet a while, my lord; the poor things have not quite din'd.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: I tell you they muſt be put to directly—I have not a moment to ſpare.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Very well, my lord—then they ſhall only juſt finiſh the handful of meat that's in the manger—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Damn the manger! I tell you I muſt go immediately.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: What, mayn't they make an end of the mouthful they're about, my lord?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: I tell you no! I'll make an end of you, you raſcal, if you don't get the carriage ready this inſtant.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Very well, my lord!—then I'll get 'em rubb'd down and put to preſently—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p:
Rubb'd down! you damn'd provoking dilatory raſcal, if they're not put to this moment, I'll
〈◊〉
down with a witneſs!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I wonder •• no'd wiſh to be a coachhorſe? poor ſouls I can never have a meal in comfort! [going towards the houſe]

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: But hark ye, Robert! go this way, or you'll ruin all—thro' the private door, which you may unbolt, at the bottom of this walk—if any of Sir Thomas's people are at the ſtables, make ſome pretence to get them out of the way—let nobody ſee you take the carriage out, be ſure, if you can poſſibly avoid it, then ſaddle La Poudre's horſe, and wait for us at that garden-gate.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Very well, my lord.—what maggot's in his head now, I wonder! not that I car'd a whiſp of hay what was going forward, if the poor beaſtes had but fill'd their bellies—it's bad enough of all conſcience to be a coach-man, but, damn it, it's worſe yet to be a coach-horſe.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Diable! for vy is all dis, mi lor?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Why, I have got into a curſed dilemma here, La Poudre, and you muſt be a damn'd raſcal to endeavour to help me out of it.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Sans doute, my lord!—aſſurément I ſal do every ting in my poſſibilité— mais vat dilemme, mi lor, is it I mus help you out?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: I had like to have been finely taken in here, La Poudre:—Emily is not Sir Thomas's daughter, but the parſon's.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Ah, morbleu! den I ſuppoſe ſhe have peu on point d'argent, littel or no moneys —not ſo grande fortune as you did expeck?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: You have hit it—therefore I have declin'd marrying her as I intended, and offer'd (inſtead) to take her into keeping.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Vous avez raiſon, mi lor; 'tis ver vel juge—and ſhe vil make ver pretty fille de joye for your keep, en verité.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Why, ay, La Poudre, tho' ſhe is not freighted for a matrimonial voyage, ſhe'd make a charming pleaſure yatch! but ſhe has refus'd that—

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Refuſe dat? la grande ſotte! oh que de great a fool!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Her puppy of a brother juſt now interrupted me in an attempt upon her, and they are gone in doors to acquaint the family of it, I ſuppoſe—now, unleſs I can contrive to carry her off, I loſe her for ever!

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Parbleu, c'eſt vrai, mi lor—it is ver true inteed.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: In hopes of which, you hear how I have order'd the carriage—now, if you think it poſſible to decoy her out, Robert and I will be ready to hurry her into it in a moment.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Je ne ſcai pas, mi lor—it vil be ver difficile—but I will try all my poſſibilité.

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: No matter what unaccountable lies you tell—

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Lie! bygar I vil lie and ſwear thro' tick and thro' tin;

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: If you ſucceed, the moment ſhe is without the garden door, do you bolt it within to prevent their tracing us; then climb over the wall directly, mount your horſe, and ſcour away as if you rode for your life.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Oui, mi lor—but vere mus I ſcoure?

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Down to the beach as hard as ever you can ride, and hail the Tarquin—bid O'Connor bring the ſkiff aſhore immediately, and both of you wait my coming to aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Je vous entend bien, mi lor— and I ſal ſcoure comme le diable!

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p: Then, if I get her but ſafe down there, I have no more to do but whiſk her on board the Tarquin, put off to ſea, and— [a noiſe heard without]

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Allez, allez, mi lor—ſomebody come—

sp.speaker: L. Sealand.
sp.p:
I am gone—ſucceed, my dear La Poudre, and you are made for ever!—now,
Venus! be propitious to my ſcheme, I'll ſail for Paphos, and there worſhip thee!

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Ma foi! it be de old gentilman himſelf come! parbleu, I no like his look—he is fort enragé—in one devil a great paſſion—mort de ma vie! I wiſh I no get break a my bone! fa, la, la, la, &c. [ſinging careleſſly]

div.stage: Sir Thomas Richacre and Dr. Goodman enter.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Where is the raſcal?

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Fa, la, la, la!—who, ſire?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: That ſcoundrel of a lord!—

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Mi lor ſcoundrel? je ne ſcais pas —I am not acquaint vid mi lor Scoundrel, ni monſieur Raſcal non plus! I have not de honneur to know de gentilmens en verité—who do you mean, ſire?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Mean, ſire! why, when I aſk for a ſcoundrel, a raſcal, and a lord, who can I mean but Lord Sealand?

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Mi lor Sealand!—

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Heaven forbid there ſhould exiſt another lord, thoſe names could be applied to!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Is the villain here yet, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: I don't know where he is, not I, nor will this fellow tell me.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Parbleu! I am amaze! je vous en prie, gentilmens, vat is all dis fracas and tintamarre?—eſt ce que you dit aſk a me, ſire, vere be mi lor Sealand?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why, who ſhould I aſk but you? do you think I enquir'd of the trees and flower-plots?

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Je vous demande pardon, dat I ave no underſtand vat you ſpeak ven you aſk or mi lor Scoundrel—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Well, now you do underſtand— where is he?

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Vat, mi lor Sealand?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Yes, you damn'd incomprehenſible puppy! Lord Sealand.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Sire, he be only juſt valk littel way down de jardin.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Down which walk?—

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Down dat a walk, ſire— [ſhewing a wrong way]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Now then, if the villain has a heart, I'll put it to the proof! [aſide]

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
Sir Thom.
sp.p: He ſha'n't be there long, a dog! nor in any other place that I am maſter of— for, as ſoon as I have told him what a ſcoundrel I think him, if he don't walk out of his own accord, I ſhall make bold to kick him out!

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Kick him out! mort de ma vie! kick a mi lor Sealand? vat, in de name of vonder, all dis mean, ſire?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: It means that your wicked lord has made a moſt infamous attempt upon my daughter's honour?

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Your daughtere, ſire!—vat daughtere?

sp.speaker: Dr. Goodman.
sp.p: My Emily—my dear, my innocent child!

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Your ſhild, ſire! be mademoiſelle Emily your ſhild?

sp.speaker: Dr. Goodman.
sp.p: She is! which that diſgrace-to-his-rank no ſooner knew, than (not content moſt poorly to reject her he had juſt before ſolicited for a wife) he wickedly endeavoured to ſeduce her to be his miſtreſs!

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Very wicked inteed, ſire!—

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Nay more, to aggravate his guilt, propoſed rewards for me, her wretched father! to be the pander to my daughter's infamy!

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Helas! c'eſt une choſe bien infame et extraordinaire, inteed! I am quite ſhocka to hear it! I no muſh vonder now de old gentilman be go kick a mi lor—but I vonder great deal you ave ſo muſh patience and philoſophie dat you no go give him littel kick too, ſire.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: 'Twould ill become my cloth to ſeek revenge—tho' I came here, I muſt confeſs, in anger; and, had I met him, ſhould have loaded him with bittereſt reproaches— but, on reflection, think it better to avoid him —if he repents his fault, I am ſatisfied!

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p:
'Tis very good of you inteed, ſire—for mi lor ave been fort mechant, very naughty I mus confeſs; and I ſhou'd be no muſh ſurpriſe if de young gentilman fight a mi lor and kill him—ecoutez!—hark a, monſieur! I think I hear de ſword claſh—oh, que oui! dey fight! dey fight! ah, mon pauvre
lor! he vill be kill! he vill be kill! and I fall loſe my place!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Kill'd! forbid it heaven! tho' he deſerves the worſt that could befall him, yet —let me endeavour to prevent more ſin!

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha! ſo far I ave tell de very pritty lie inteed, to get dem all out of de vay—now, vile de coaſt be cleare, I go to de maiſon, and try all my poſſibilité to get mademoiſelle to mi lor—eh! parbleu, it vill be no politique to come back dis way and meet a les gentilſhommes again! vat I ſall do, ma foi!—let a me conſidere— [going]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: George—brother! where are you, my dear, cruel George?—

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Quel bonheur! here come de lady quite apropos!—now for de bold ſtroke— ah miſerable que je ſuis! la peur me fait mourir! I am frighten to death! help a meurtre! meurtre!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Ah, murder? merciful heaven! I fear'd as much, and therefore followed— where? who?

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Ah, madame! I am frighten out of my ſenſe! Young monſieur Goodaman be gone out of de gate of de jardin to fight a mi lor Sealand, and I juſtement hear de ſword claſh and piſtol fire!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Gracious heaven defend him!—brother! father! help! murder! help!

div.stage: Exit Emily the way L. Sealand went.

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha! dat is bien fait —ver vell done inteed! [looking after her] you be goot girl, run ver vell—mi lor vill keſh you dans un moment, and carry you quite away! ha, ha, ha, ha!

div.stage: Sir Thomas Richacre re-enters at the upper End of the Stage, looking about.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Where, in the devil's name, has he hid himſelf?

sp.speaker: La Poudre.
sp.p: Ah, ma foi! here come old gentilman again! now I muſt run bolt a de jardin door apres mademoiſelle, climb over de vall, (take care I no break a my neck tho') monter á cheval, and ſcoure down to de beeche as if de devil vas ſcoure after me!—ha, ha, ha, ha! bygar, I am von very greata deviliſh lucky rogue! ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain to ſeek him here, ſir; he muſt certainly have returned up the yewtree walk to the houſe, while we have been this way, and may offer freſh inſult to my ſiſter—the thought alarms me!—let me fly to her protection!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p:
Why, there's no finding the dog any where, Doctor—he is not in the garden I'm ſure—unleſs he has hid himſelf at the
bottom of the canal—I'll have it dragg'd, and if I find him there, I ſha'n't have quite ſo bad an opinion of him as I had.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Let us hope, ſir, he has reflected on the heinouſneſs of his behaviour, and withdrawn himſelf privately through ſhame.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Shame, a villain! he was not aſham'd of committing the offence, but I ſuppoſe he'd bluſh up to the eyes to aſk pardon; nay, run the beſt friend he has in the world through the body, or blow his brains out, ſooner than do it!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: It is to that falſe ſhame, ſir, we may attribute moſt of the impious duels, by which our laws divine and human are daily ſcandaliz'd and broken!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ay, it's too true, Doctor—the more the pity!—come, George—heyday! what's gone with him?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: He went in doors to Emily, I believe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Well—come, my good friend, let us forget this puppy that has vex'd us— 'thank heaven no harm came of it—I think we had e'en as well go tell your ſweet girl what I was propoſing, when George and ſhe came in from Sealand; and have the wedding celebrated as ſoon as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Dear ſir, conſider once more the vaſt diſparity before you finally determine— the obligations you have conferr'd on me and mine already, are never to be cancell'd, but this unthought-of condeſcenſion—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p:
No more, no more, my dear old friend! I have conſidered it thoroughly, and (if you will ſo far indulge me) it ſhall be ſo—
we'll ſhew the libertine we can ſet a proper value upon merit, without the recommendation of fortune, tho' he cou'd not, by offering her a huſband not much inferior to himſelf, who will love her and protect her!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Have you ſeen my ſiſter, ſir?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Not ſince we left her in the houſe; is ſhe not there?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: No, ſir! Patty ſays, that fearful of my having a rencounter with Lord Sealand, ſhe follow'd me into the garden.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Bleſs me! where can ſhe have gone ſo ſuddenly?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why the devil's in the people to day, I think, i'my conſcience—one can't turn one's head, but, like goblins and fairies, or a jugler's cups and balls, they're vaniſh'd!— Odzookers! now I think a little, my mind miſgives me—ſure that damn'd fellow, Sealand, has not convey'd her off!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Which way, dear ſir? the garden door, you ſee, is ſhut, and faſt bolted, which, if they had gone out of it, muſt have been left open.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why, Emily! Sealand! Frenchman! ſcoundrel!—where, in the devil's name, are you all got to? [running up and down the ſtage]

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Sir! ſir! your worſhip!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: What are you bawling about, you raſcal? is not one enough at a time?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Your worſhip!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: What does the blockhead ſtare ſo at? have you ſeen your young lady any where lately?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: N—n—no, your worſhip!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Nor Lord Sealand?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: N—n—no, ſir! I ha'n't ſeen ne'er a one of them ſince tea-time—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Then what do you come to plague us now for, you puppy!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Lord, your honour! I only came to tell your worſhip the poor woman, Dame Quickſet, that lives at the cottage where your honours all went after dinner to day, is begging for dear life to ſpeak to your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: I am buſy now—I can't ſpeak to her—zounds! I cou'd not ſpeak to the great mogul if he was here—why, Emily! Sealand!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Dear ſir, be patient for a moment —it may be ſomething concerning my child— pray let her ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: D. Quick.
sp.p: Where is his good worſhip? I muſt ſpeak with un, for it be upon life and death! [ſhe enters] O, heaven bleſs your worſhip! you're undone! you're undone!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: So I have been juſt thinking!— but how, how?

sp.speaker: D. Quick.
sp.p: Young madam! your daughter! your daughter!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: What of her!—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Speak! ſpeak!—

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Where is ſhe, good woman, where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: D. Quick.
sp.p: Heaven knows where by this, not I!—ſome vile villains have kidnap'd the precious lady away, to have their wicked will of her; or elſe (for the lucre of gold) to ſell her for a neger-ſlave, or a turk, I do verily believe!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: A negro or a turk! why what a plague does the woman mean?

sp.speaker: D. Quick.
sp.p: Why, an't pleaſe your worſhip, a ſtrange outlandiſh looking man came galloping down our lane not a minute agone, whipping and ſpurring poor beaſt like any mad! and a fine chariot came driving a'ter him from your worſhip's garden door, as thof 'twou'd ha' tore the ground to very bits; with ſomebody ſcreaming and crying i'th' inſide on't as thof they had been murder'd! and, as it paſs'd by our hut, who ſhould I ſee it was but the ſweet young Lady Richacre, your worſhip's daughter, with ſome vile rogue ſitting beſide and holding her, diſguiſed like a gentleman!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: As ſure as death it was that dog Sealand!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Good heaven protect my child!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Follow me, William! and help to get arms and horſes ready!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Od rot un! I'll take blunderbuſs from hall-chimney for myſelf, and, if I come up with un, I'll make un remember the day o'the month I warrant un!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Metre! John! Coachman I ſaddle all the horſes! load all the fire arms! raiſe the whole county! blood! I'll blow the villains all to pieces!

div.head: ACT V. Scene, a Parlour.

sp.speaker: PATTY.
sp.p: DEAR heart, how I tremble! I am ſadly afraid they won't overtake them—lud, lud! I wiſh ſomebody was come back again, for I begin to be afraid to ſtay in the houſe any longer—who knows but they'll come and run away with me next! O, I wiſh William was come back! I hope the dear ſoul won't come to any harm!—lud, lud! what a twitter am I in!—and what can have become of my father?—ſure he has not follow'd them a-foot —hark! did not I hear a noiſe? perhaps I forgot to faſten the hall-door in my fright, and ſomebody is coming to run away with me!

div.stage: Metre enters out of breath, ſhe runs and embraces him.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: O dear father! is it you? I am glad you are come back!—where have you been? what have you heard? have you ſeen any thing of them?

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: What! hath no one returned yet, Martha?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Nobody but you, father.—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p:
Goodlack! goodlack! was there ever the like heard of! neither tale nor tidings can I learn, and I have run up and down almoſt
every lane in the pariſh, untill my poor old legs are juſt ready to drop off!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: You had better ſit down, father, and reſt yourſelf, while I get ſomething for you.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Sit down, child? no, I will neither eat, nor drink, nor reſt, untill the precious lady is found!—I wanted but to know if any one had been more proſperous than myſelf, before I journeyed to any vaſt diſtance; and ſince no one hath, I will travel unto the world's end, but I will find her!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Pray, dear father, don't—for, if you ſhould chance to meet with the villains, they may murder you, and then come and run away with me!—indeed I can't ſtay here any longer by myſelf with ſuch dreadful apprehenſions— O! I am terrified out of my ſenſes!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Be compoſed, my good child—they muſt be hardened wretches indeed to ſlay a poor old man like me, who could aſſail them with nought but prayers and ſupplications— therefore, make faſt the door after me, and look heedfully unto the manſion, child, while I— [going]—as I am a ſinner, my reverend maſter is returned!—I pray heaven he bringeth joyful tidings!—

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Ha? what's that I hear? joyful tidings, ſaid you? is ſhe found, Metre? is ſhe found?

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: No, truly, if your reverence hath not been ſo proſperous!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Diſtraction! O my child! my loſt, loſt, violated child!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: The Philiſtines are come upon her, verily!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Here, Patty! where are you?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Lord! here's his worſhip come back, ſir—who knows but he may have had better luck —I am in great hopes—

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: No, no, no! there are no hopes! no hopes!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Patty! Metre!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Here, your worſhip!—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Who's at home? has nobody found this raſcal yet? nobody return'd?

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Yes, an't pleaſe your worſhip, his reverence is returned, and ſo am I.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: And ſo are you!—why I did not know you had been any where—where the devil did you hide yourſelf? I call'd and bawl'd for you before I went out 'till I was hoarſe again, but could not find you.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Indeed, your worſhip, my poor father has been running all over the pariſh, ſeeking for young madam, 'till he is almoſt dead.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Well! and has he found her?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Oh, no, no, no!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why then I wiſh he was quite dead —and I wiſh I was dead—and we were all dead! and buried! and—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Good your worſhip wax not wroth with your poor old ſervant! I did my beſt, in truth; and was juſt going to repeat my feeble endeavours as his reverence came in.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Dear ſir, adviſe me—I am almoſt diſtracted!—what ſhall I do? where ſhall I ſeek her?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: I know no more than you—almoſt diſtracted, quotha? zounds! I have been ſtark mad this half hour!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Will your good worſhip pleaſe to repoſe you in your eaſy chair?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Repoſe the devil!—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Mercy on us!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Which way did you go, Doctor?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: I went firſt, ſir, to Lord Sealand's houſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Pſha! that I know already, for I was there juſt after you—what could induce you to go there? you might be ſure enough he would not carry her home—which way did George go?

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: I know not, ſir—heaven will, I hope, direct him better!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: He can't have worſe luck than I had go which way he will—for, ſo far from a coach or a chariot, I could not ſee ſo much as a cart or a wheel-barrow—but, come, come—don't let us ſtand chattering here—let us go look ſomewhere or other— [going]

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p:
Hilli ho! my hearts!—what cheer, honies?—what, all under hatches? tumble up, tumble up, my jewels!— [he enters] By my
ſoul! this is the ſtrangeſt veſſel I ever ſtuck foot aboard—the devil a hand is there walking deck to keep watch! ſo, fait, I e'en made bold to take a peep into the cabin!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Who the devil are you, ſir? what do you want here?

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Arrah, be eaſy, my jewel! don't put yourſelf out of your latitude, and you'll know who I am preſently—but why won't you ſtation a hand upon deck yonder to keep a bit of a look out? or you may be boarded by a land-pirate, honey!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Go, Martha, and make faſt the door, child.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Dear heart! I am almoſt afraid this ſtrange man is come to run away with me! [aſide]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: What's your buſineſs? what do you want of me?

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: What do I want with you? the devil a toothful do I want of you, but a little civil diſcourſe; nor that neither, unleſs you are the commander here.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Well, ſir, I am the commander as you call it—What then?

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Why then—I'll lower my top-ſail to you, honey! [pulling off his hat]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: But—what's your buſineſs? for I'm in haſte—

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Why you are to know, joy, I am juſt come full ſail upon the outſide of a horſe (with another in tow) from the ſalt-ſea-ſhore, to bring you advice of a ſweet cratur, a female young woman, (belonging here) and my maſter Lord Sealand—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Lord Scoundrel!—

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Indeed you may ſay that—more pity the two words ſhould ever be ſplic'd together!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: But your news, ſir, your news!

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Why, you muſt know, I receav'd orders from Mounſeer Powder-puff, my lord's walley-de-ſhaver, to have our ſkiff ready to carry my lord, and the young woman I mention'd, aboard our cutter, the Tarquin—but I ſoon found, by her unwillingneſs, that ſhe was not a volunteer of her own accord; but had been preſs'd into the ſarvice without giving her conſent to it—ſo, faith! I began to be a little queer with my lord about it; for the ſweet cratur look'd as innocent as a ſucking dove, ay, or a new-born dove's egg! and I determin'd not to aid and aſſiſt at making her otherwiſe!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Eternal bleſſings on you for your goodneſs!

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Devil a goodneſs in the caſe, honey —'twas no more than the duty of every honeſt man that is not a rogue!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Give me your hand, my heart of oak! I am your friend for ever!

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: So, while we were raving and ſquabbling within half a cable's length of land, a good clever likely young jontleman, and a carrotty-pated livery-ſervant, came galloping and ſplaſhing into the ſalt-ſea, as if they were riding poſt over to France or Holland! for their horſes were fairly afloat, and half way to the ſkiff in the turning of a handſpike.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: So, friend!—

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p:
Hollo! you young harebrains! ſays I—have a care you don't run foul of our
little nut-ſhell, and ſpill us all! upon which the poor girl cry'd out, it was her brother!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Her brother!

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Devil fire me! ſays little Brian O'Connor (that's myſelf) if their beaſts ſhall board us, and ſend us to the bottom, if he was your brother and ſiſter too! but, do you hear, young jontleman? ſays I, have a little wit in your folly, and don't fink your friends and your foes together, but take in a reef a two and we'll be alongſide you preſently.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: That was right, friend, that was right!

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Upon which, you may take your ſwear, my bug-of-a-lord did all he could to prevent my carrying the boat aſhore—and, at laſt, when he found nothing elſe would do, (nor that neither) was trying to huſsle me overboard—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Was it poſſible!

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Indeed it was not!—for, as ſoon as I perceav'd it, Oho! thinks little Brian, are you for that fun? I'll be bound I match you to a tittle, my jewel! ſo, upon my conſcience, I made no more ceremony, but gave him as pretty a genteel lift as you ſhall ſee in a ſummer's day, and capſiz'd him (ſouſe!) headlong into the wet ocean! where he look'd, for all the world, like the gold and filver fiſh folks keep in glaſs waſhing-rubs!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! well done, well done, i'faith!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: But (notwithſtanding his demerits) he was not drowned, ſir, I hope!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: There we differ, old Stave, for once—for I hope he was.

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: No, faith, ſir, as ill luck would have it, he was not drown'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: The more the pity, ſay I.

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Upon my conſcience, ſir, you ſay very right—it was God's mercy and a thouſand pities ſure enough! but I take it he was a little damp or ſo, for when he ſcrambled aſhore, the ſalt brine ran from him by pailfuls.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha! I ſhall burſt, I ſhall burſt! upon ſecond thoughts I am glad the dog was not drown'd, for if he had, I ſhould have been kill'd outright.

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Yes, fait, and ſo would he too!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: But how ended the matter, pray ſir?

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: O, it was ſoon over, honey! for when I had thrown the whale into Jonas's belly—

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Jonas into the whale's belly, I apprehend you mean, ſir!

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Well! the whale into Jonas, or Jonas into the whale, it's all one an't it? —when I had given my lord a ſummerſet, I ſay, and ſpilt him into the ocean, we got aſhore preſently—but, as the young jontleman was hoiſting his ſiſter out of the boat, his draggle-tail'd lordſhip lent him ſuch a pat o'the cheek, as was enough to break his handſome face, or put one of his forecaſtle lights out!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: The cowardly villain! but he repaid it, I hope?

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p:
Och! I'll be bound he did—and with intereſt too—for he had the honour of horſe-whipping his lordſhip to his heart's content! and (by way of premium) I divarted
myſelf the mean time with beating his impudent French walley-de-ſhaver!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Bravo! bravo! ha, ha, ha! but what became of the livery-ſervant all this while? ſure he was not idle?

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: What, the lad with the bunch of carrots growing on his head? indeed he was not—for he had no ſooner handed the poor frighted girl out of the gangway, and brought the two horſes they went, and I came upon, to an anchor; but the tight lad beſeag'd the coach-box, took it by ſtorm, and is now piloting the young jontleman and lady ſafe into port here, aboard my lord's own chariot, fait: leaving him and his raſcally companions to pad the hoof, and trudge home upon their ten toes!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Odſo! then let's go meet 'em! they can't be far off by this, and I long to ſee the dear rogues again— [going]—hark! ſure I hear a carriage ſtop.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: My lady's come back, ſir! my lady's come back! young Mr. Goodman and William have found her, and they are all come back together!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Rejoice and ſing! kill the fatted calf and be merry, for the loſt ſheep is found!

div.stage: She runs to Dr. Goodman, Sir Thomas Richacre catches George in his arms.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: My dear, dear, brave boy! thou'rt welcome home again!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [to Dr. Goodman] O my lov'd ſire! ſcarce did I know my father, ere I was torn from him! but am reſtor'd (thank heaven!) to his paternal arms!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Thanks, gracious providence! I ſee my child again!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Amen!—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Odzookers! George! I have been in a plaguy pucker about you, you rogue!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Sir, I am eternally bound to you for this ſolicitude! And, was not my dear father exceedingly alarm'd?
[to Dr. Goodman]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Alarm'd! why I tell you I have been almoſt out of my wits about you both!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Sir, I am bound to you for ever! but, my dear father— [to Dr. Goodman]—is not he happy too that my ſiſter, his ſweet daughter, is ſafe reſtored?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ay, that he is, I'll anſwer for him—and, as you have ſo bravely help'd to recover a daughter for him, the leaſt he can do in return is to provide you with a father, by reſtoring me my ſon!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Sir! what does my patron ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Say?—ecod I don't know what to ſay?—only that, in having you for my heir, I am father to one of the beſt and braveſt lads in the kingdom!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Father—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Yes, my dear boy! I am indeed! —your father! George, your father! [embracing him] Odzookers, Doctor, I could contain myſelf no longer, faith!

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: Dear ſir, he is your own, and truly worth the claiming!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Indulgent powers! is it poſſible? [aſide]

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p:
O good gracious! ma'am! here's good news for you.
[aſide to Emily]

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Wonderful! wonderful! moſt wonderful!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Am I in a dream!—

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Upon my conſcience I can't tell— but, if you are, you have had a very pleaſant ride in your ſleep!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Dear ſirs! what am I to think?— within theſe few hours I thought myſelf the ſon of this worthy divine, and this ſweet maid, your daughter, ſir— [to Sir Thomas Richacre] we then were wretched beyond idea, ſuppoſing ourſelves the iſſue of one parent! and now, ſir—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: And now, my dear boy! all is ſet right—you are my ſon, my own fleſh and blood! at leaſt your mother, Lady Richacre, (who was a pattern of conjugal fidelity) told me ſo—and Emily is as ſurely Dr. Goodman's daughter. [George kneels to Sir Thomas, who raiſes and embraces him]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Tranſporting ſounds! then we may yet be happy! [aſide]

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Devil burn me! but this makes out the old ſaying good—that it's a wiſe father knows his own child—O no, fait, I don't mean ſo neither—(tho' that may be true too) but, it's a wiſe child knows it's own father!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
Moſt honour'd parent!
[to Sir Thomas] (if I really am ſo bleſt) may I preſume to aſk why we have both been bred in ſuch a mutual error?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: I'll tell thee, George—I had obſerv'd, with great concern, how ſeldom young men, bred in the inſolent pride of inheriting great eſtates, deſerv'd them!—I am a whimſical old fellow, you know—and therefore propoſed to, and prevail'd on, my reſpected friend (as we became widowers almoſt together) to join with me in a project I had formed (in imitation of the Spectator's Leontine and Eudoxus) of exchanging children for a time—hoping thereby to render you more worthy than you might otherwiſe have been, of the fortune and title you was born to—the experiment was a ſingular one, I own, but the event has fully juſtified it! [George bows]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: And, ſir!—if I dare aſk one queſtion more—what recompence did you purpoſe to this young lady for being deluded with ſuch an imaginary grandeur?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what is he ſaying? [aſide]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Was it to realize the golden dream?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why, I had ſome ſuch notion, indeed, George.—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: If I remember right the ſtory you alluded to, ſir, the good, the generous Eudoxus, join'd the young and loving pair: is that my ſire's intention? or (which I dread to aſk!)— is it to—marry her yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ha? what! marry Emily myſelf? bleſs her dear little heart, heaven forbid! no, no, I had a younger ſpark in my eye for her—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Benignity itſelf! he means my George, I'm certain, and I ſhall yet be bleſt! [aſide]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Then, ſir, I may ſpeak plainer—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: What will the dear youth ſay! [aſide]

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: And declare, that I am vet a beggar, if you add not to my late acquiſition of fortune, the ſupreme delight of reſtoring this lov'd maid to the ſtation ſhe was bred in, by permitting me ſtill to call this beſt of men my father!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: What do you aſk me for? ſhe's none of mine, you fool! why don't you aſk the Doctor?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
[to Sir Thomas] My indulgent father!
[to Dr. Goodman] O, ſir! either my behaviour has hitherto been unfilial, or you will kindly receive me for your ſon again.

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: My ever deareſt ſon!—take her, and may heaven ſhower down eternal bleſſings on you both!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Amen!—

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Ay, and ſo be it too, ſay I!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Now, if my Emily thinks me not unworthy—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: O talk not ſo! 'tis I that am unworthy—yet wherefore?—if deſert conſiſted but in riches, then I were indeed deficient! but, conſcious of a mind ſuperior to the diſtinctions of birth and fortune, I feel that I deſerve your love! for, had our conditions really been as we imagined, preferring thee, the worthieſt, to the moſt wealthy, I ſhould have gloried in my acquiſition more than in a conqueſt of the moſt exalted!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: I know it, my ſweet Emily! I know it.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
And, if my preſerver loves like me, he will not aſk, but take my trembling hand;
aſſur'd, that he poſſeſſes wholly my fond, my beating heart!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Thus then I take thy ſnowy hand! here ſeal my faith! [kiſſing her hand] and henceforth we are one!

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Ay, and a very pretty ſplice you have both made on't!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [to Sir Thomas] I have ſo full a ſenſe, ſir, of your moſt unexampled goodneſs, in firſt adopting your poor girl, and now confirming thus your favour, I cannot thank you as I ought!—let theſe duteous, grateful tears ſpeak for me! [falling on her knee]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Riſe, riſe, my ſweet child! you are my daughter now indeed! [raiſes and kiſſes her]

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: [wiping his eyes] Well! I wiſh I may never taſte another cheekful of beef and biſcuit, or a ſup of grog again, if this is not as pretty a piece of buſineſs—

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: My good friend! the preſerver of my Emily! amid theſe ſeveral tranſports I have too long overlook'd you!

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p:
Och! no offence, gra! I have been overlooking you too, 'till I don't know what ails me fait! but I've a notion the ſalt-water that ſpalpeen of a lord ſplaſh'd in my face when I tilted him overboard, had not got out of the corners of my eyes before! for ſome drops trickled down the ſcuppers of my cheeks into my mouth juſt now that taſted quite brackiſh! they could not be tears ſure! for (tho' we Iriſhmen are apt to make blunders) a
weather-beaten chap like myſelf would not cry, ſure, at what he's ſo well pleas'd with!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: You have a double title to my gratitude, as I receiv'd aſſiſtance from you againſt your own maſter; not fearing, in the cauſe of virtue, to offend the wretch you ſerv'd!

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: I'll tell you what, honey!—Saint Patrick be thankful, I'm never afraid of doing what's right!—for tho' I'm but a menial man of low degree, I am ſprung from a very great offspring, and have got the thick blood of the kings of Ireland bubbling in my veins, joy!— and, in my fooliſh way of thinking, ſo far from offending, I ſarv'd my maſter moſt faithfully by not ſarving him at all at all, in ſuch an unjontlemanlike undertaking!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: You are a right honeſt tar! and ſhall never ſerve any one again while you live.

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Indeed and I will always ſarve both you and yours with all the blood in my bones!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
How, or in what words ſhall I expreſs my very fervent thanks to you, for having ſav'd a helpleſs creature from what I dread to think of!
[to O'Connor]

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: I'll tell you how you ſhall thank me, jewel! by holding your ſweet tongue, and never ſaying another word about it!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Generous man! my deeds ſhall then ſpeak for me.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: Dear father! now every thing elſe is ſettled ſo nicely, do, pray, put in a word for poor William.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: And yourſelf, eh, Martha?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, father.

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Well, I will adventure to addreſs their honours—hem! hem! good your worſhip!—and good your reverence!—this ſeeming an auſpicious hour, your poor old ſervant hath an humble boon to crave.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: What is it, old ſilver-locks?

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: That it may pleaſe your honours, when the bans of matrimony are publiſhed between my dear and honourable young maſter and miſtreſs, (as I truſt his reverence will not approve they ſhould be married by licence) the names of my poor child, Martha Metre, ſpinſter—and her choſen ſpouſe and helpmate, William Strongbow, batchelor, both of this pariſh, may be permitted moſt humbly to follow.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: William Strongbow! what, young carrotty-poll? where is the red-headed rogue? I have not ſeen him ſince he ſcal'd the coach-box.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: He is in the hall, I believe, father! [aſide to him]

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: William Strongbow! approach his worſhip's preſence.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: Did your worſhip pleaſe to want me?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Ay, come hither, William—I am told you have behav'd like a man of Kent to day, in helping to reſcue my maid of Kent here from Lord Sealand and his myrmidons?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: I did my beſt, an't like your worſhip, as I was in duty bound.

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: And likewiſe that you and Patty want to make a match together?

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: If your worſhip and his reverence pleaſe to give us leave. [bowing]

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: What ſay you, Patty?

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: William has ſpoke my mind, your honours! [curtſying]

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Why then marry away, you young rogues, as faſt as you can! you have my goodwill.

sp.speaker: Metre, William, and Patty.
sp.p: I humbly thank your worſhip!—

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: And mine!

sp.speaker: Metre, William, and Patty.
sp.p: I humbly thank your reverence!—

sp.speaker: Dr. Good.
sp.p: And I pray heaven to bleſs and proſper you!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Amen!—

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: And in reward for your ſervice to day, I'll make a man of you, my boy!

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: I moſt humbly thank your noble worſhip's honour and goodneſs!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: And, with your leave, ſir, I will give Patty a little portion.

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: 'Thank you kindly, ſir! and may you and my dear young lady be as happy together as you deſerve!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
I thank you, Patty!—may you,
[to Patty and William] and every virtuous pair be no leſs ſo!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: Amen!—

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: And now, Patty, we ſhall be as merry as grigs, or as midſummer-day is long!

sp.speaker: Patty.
sp.p: That we ſhall, William! and I long for the wedding to be over, that, inſtead of plain Patty, I may hear myſelf call'd Mrs. Strongbow!

sp.speaker: Sir Thom.
sp.p: Now, I believe, all parties are rewarded and ſatisfied, except the poor Quickſets; and they too ſhall partake the happineſs they, by the timely alarm given us, were in great meaſure the means of, and never be poor, or want for any thing again, unleſs it be health, and that the richeſt of us can't beſtow! And ſo, every thing is ſettled, and we are all happy! are we not, old boy? ſhake hands, my heart of oak! what ſay you?

sp.speaker: O'Connor.
sp.p: Why, ſir, I ſay—the honour of wagging a fiſt with you wou'd make the happy if I was ever ſo miſerable! but I'm after thinking the young jontleman and his little ſweetlips there, ay, and t'other young couple too, won't be quite eaſy 'till they have ſhook hands and been ſplic'd together in church, fait!

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p:
The idea tranſports me!—my Emily!—my deſtin'd bride! we now approach the height of human bliſs! bleſt as we are in the paternal care of theſe our beſt of fathers, the affections of our faithful friends and ſervants, and the fruition of our mutual diſintereſted love!—the vices of that miſcreant lord, you happily was delivered from, are puniſhed by an indelible diſgrace! while the
virtues of this circle are rewarded with a perfect, and, I hope 'twill prove, a laſting felicity!

sp.speaker: Metre.
sp.p: AMEN!

l.hi: OUR ſilly author fain would have me ſpeak
Something I underſtand no more than Greek;
His epilogue—which he, ſure, thinks as fine
As if inſpir'd by Phoebus and the Nine!

lg.l: Such moral leſſons—ſage, inſtructive rules—

l.hi: Drawn from learn'd folios, and the antient ſchools.
Morals, ſaid I, the ſchools, and huge dull folios?
Why, ſir, theſe ſort of things ſhould be quite olios!
Compos'd of choice tid-bits cull'd up and down,

lg.l: From the gay fancies that amuſe this town—

l.hi: With ſcavoir-vivres let your ſcene be laid,
Tell us of coteries, or a maſquerade;
Of ſuch materials epilogues are made!
Yet ſtill he begs that I would plead his cauſe,
And ſay, "the piece conforms to critic laws
In ſcene, time, action; and his further plan
To draw men as they are, not more than man,
Some good, ſome bad"—thus tritely on he ran.
Preach this yourſelf for me, ſir, I replied,
An epilogue I want where may be tried
My comic talents, after this dull part,

lg.l: Which was not worth the getting off by heart—

l.hi: Give me a taſte of gay Thalia's art!
In witty verſe to ſatirize the beaux,
And ſwear they know no bliſs beyond fine cloaths:

lg.l: While ſmirking—leering—playing with my fan—

l.hi: I may attract each modiſh, ape of man,
And make him feel—if feel ſuch beings can.
Speak ſcandal of the ladies—ſay the cits
Have hearty ſtomachs, and but puny wits;
Nay, any thing to pleaſe and to amuſe

lg.l: This gen'rous circle—politics or news;—

l.hi: Joyful I'd come, on ſuch an errand ſent,

lg.l: And you ſtill more approv'd The MAID of KENT!
